The special buses benefitted many commuters who were otherwise dependent on private bus operators, who usually hike their rates during the festive season. “Private non-AC seater buses had increased ticket fares to the down south districts to upwards Rs 900,” said G Anuja, a college student in the city. However, TNSTC special buses were available to almost every district from Rs 550 onwards. “It has also become simple to book a ticket online, instead of waiting in queues at the bus stand with uncertainty,” she said.

TNSTC usually operates special buses during festive seasons like Pongal, Diwali, Ayudha Pooja and Tamil New Year. These buses are operated in addition to the 127 buses to Salem from Gandhipuram, and 55 buses to Trichy from Singanallur bus stand. During the festive season, all the buses to the two destinations departed from CODISSIA grounds to reduce congestion in the main bus stands.

Title: Uttam to KTR: List at least 10 promises kept
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Hyderabad: Stating that TRS has made 500 election promises since 2014, Congress on Friday threw a challenge at municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao to list out at least 10 major promises the ruling party fulfilled so far.

“TRS is managing elections and not really contesting them. Everyone knows that TRS had copied Congress manifesto and announced it with minor changes in the December 2018 Assembly elections. Congress stands for originality. TRS is a cocktail of disgruntled leaders. Half of KCR’s cabinet and three-fourth of TRS MLAs are migrants from other parties,” Telangana Congress president N Uttam Kumar Reddy said.

Addressing street corner meetings in Huzurnagar on Friday, Uttam ridiculed TRS leaders for accusing Congress of copying TRS schemes in its manifesto. Even the Rs 5 meal scheme was originally started by Congress on March 1, 2014 in GHMC area, he said.

TRS government neither completed any irrigation nor power project started by KCR. The projects inaugurated by TRS government so far were all started by previous Congress governments,” Uttam added.

Title: Apparel cluster yet to streamline plastic waste disposal
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Tirupur: The Tirupur apparel cluster has failed to streamline the disposal of plastic wastes despite the state government giving its exemption a year ago to the export units to utilize banned single-use plastics.

The apparel units use single-use plastics with thickness of 20-60 micron to pack finished goods and wrap fabrics and other materials. In a month, 500 metres of plastic wastes are generated in the cluster.

“The corporation receives only around 6mt plastic and other non-biodegradable wastes daily. Going by the number of industrial units from all sectors, the number is very less. We handle more than 460mt wastes, including 207mt wet wastes and 253mt dry wastes daily,” corporation city health officer C Boopathi said.

An official of the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board said, “Many industrial units dump plastic wastes and other non-biodegradable wastes in open or sometimes in waterbodies.”

The corporation has signed a memorandum of understanding with Nothing Is Waste, a non-governmental organisation, for collecting and disposing industrial wastes. The organisation operates two segregation-cum-baling units at Thennampalayam.

“We mainly receive plastic wastes, carton box wastes, clothes and other office-use wastes. Though many plastic or other wastes can be recycled, it could not be done because the industrial units fail to segregate them properly. We could see that dumping of foams utilized in embroidery units were major wastes that hurt environment,” Mohammed Rizaz of Nothing Is Waste said.

Owner of a computer embroidery unit said, “More than 250mt foam wastes would be generated in Tirupur cluster in a month. Since there were no takers, most of the units would be sending those wastes to other processing units to utilize them as fuel in boilers, which is also harmful to the environment. Some of the embroidery units were dumping them in open and waterbodies. A private firm offered services of disposing the foam wastes, but it demanded Rs10 per kg. We would be ready to engage such firms only if they demand Rs2-3 per kg for the disposal.”

Tirupur Exporters’ Association president Raja M Shanmugham said, “We expect the corporation to come up with a plan for disposal.”

Title: Chennai: Family of engineer killed in Kashmir to get Rs 1.81 crore
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: An accident claims tribunal in the city directed an insurance firm to pay Rs 1.82 crore to the family of a man who was killed after he was struck down by a tipper truck at a dam site in Kashmir. The city resident was working as a manager at a dam site in the north Indian site when the accident happened in 2013.

According to the petition filed by Pushpa Latha and her two sons, her husband S Soundararaj was working at Gurez dam site in Kashmir when he met with the accident. A heavy tipper lorry came from behind and knocked Soundararaj down. In the impact, he sustained fatal injuries and died on the spot, the petition stated.

The counsel for the truck owner denied the allegations stating that the truck driver had operated the vehicle at normal speed and unexpectedly, the deceased fell in front of the vehicle. Despite attempts by the driver to avoid hitting the man, the accident happened due to the negligence of Soundararaj, the counsel stated. After perusing the submissions, the tribunal held that the accident happened only due to the rash and negligent driving by the truck driver. The tribunal noted that the deceased was 50 years old at the time of the accident and was working as a manager at a construction company and was earning over 1lakh per month.

Title: Increased river traffic, illegal fishing pose grave threat to Gangetic dolphins
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

According to experts, around 3,500 dolphins live in Ganga and its tributaries in India.

MEERUT: The recovery of the carcass of a dolphin killed by a harpoon in Hastinapur wildlife sanctuary recently has exposed the chinks in the measures to conserve the endangered Gangetic dolphins .

According to experts, around 3,500 dolphins live in Ganga and its tributaries in India. The species is concentrated in the upper periphery of Uttar Pradesh close to Uttarakhand where a Ramsar site (Between Garh Ganga and Narora) is earmarked exclusively for dolphin conservation. Other such regions in UP are Kanpur, Allahabad, Mirzapur, Etawah etc. In Bihar and West Bengal, the habitat is uniformly divided with the highest concentration in Vikramshila Gangetic Dolphin Sanctuary developed in late 1990s.

Despite concerted efforts by various agencies, a plethora of factors still continue to pose grave threat to the species. These include poaching for oil, pollution and increased traffic in waterbodies.

Shahnawaz Khan, a WWF India field unit officer currently involved in the conservation of dolphins in the Upper Ganga region near Bijnor and Ramsar site of west UP, said, “The species is generally killed for its oil which makes an excellent bait for catfish, considered to be prize catch for a hunter. Catfish easily gets attracted to the smell of the oil.”

River dolphin expert Sunil Chaudhary said, “We have worked strenuously to increase the dolphin population in Vikramshila since late 90s. Due to this, the count rose from 95 to 237 within a couple of years. However, there is a sharp decline of around 20% in the last two years due to the introduction of inland waterways. Government has declared the stretch between Haldia in West Bengal and Varanasi in UP as National Waterway Number 1 in which ships and huge boats require a continuous depth of at least three metres for travel. This requires dredging, a process that emits powerful vibrations. As Gangetic dolphins are blind, they navigate according to their own sound vibrations. The manmade ones greatly unsettle them. That is one of the major reasons behind the decline in their population.”

Notably, development of waterways is one of the key projects of BJP government at the Centre.

Syed Ainul Hussain, senior scientist at Wildlife Institute of India in Dehradun, said, “Even though the government is keen on dolphin conservation, infrastructure development is also high on its agenda. Water transport system and aquatic life, particularly dolphins, cannot coexist. One has to be sacrificed to save the other.” “We have identified 12 zones of 30km each that can be developed into sanctuaries. One of them has already been approved by the UP government near Allahabad,” he added.

The only authentic comparative statement can be made from a yearly census by the WWF India along with the UP forest division in the Bijnor-Narora stretch. While 30 dolphins were spotted in the stretch in 2015, the number rose to 36 in October 2019.

Suresh Babu, director of River Basins and Water Policy, WWF India, said, “The key element to conservation of wildlife is engagement of local communities. Over the years, we have developed Ganga Mitras and Dolphin Mitras in Bijnor-Narora region, and sensitized them towards conservation of dolphins, gharials and turtles. The results have been quite encouraging. Engagement of riverbank farmers not only reduced the use of harmful pesticides but also decreased illegal fishing considerably. Continuous dialogues with government agencies have also helped. A dip in effluent emissions has also helped dolphins thrive. We look forward to replicate the model in other areas like Kanpur downstream and Chambal in Etawah.”

Title: Chennai: Three bridges to be retrofitted at Rs 15 crore
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Parthasarathy bridge in Old Washermenpet is one of the three structures set to undergo retrofitting

CHENNAI: Three bridges in North Chennai, each more than 50 years old, are set to be retrofitted this year as the city corporation has found out, after various tests, that the bearings have worn out and repair is imminent. In coordination with the city police, Greater Chennai Corporation will also work out a traffic plan to ensure that commuters are not affected when the work is taken up.

The Vaithyanathan bridge in Tondiarpet, Parthasarathy bridge in Old Washermenpet and the bridge across the Captain Cotton Canal along Meenambal Road in MKB Nagar will be taken up for rehabilitation and retrofitting at an estimated Rs 15 crore, corporation officials said.

An official with the bridges department said retrofitting is an economical alternative to replacing or reconstruction. “These are old bridges and if retrofitted using modern techniques, they will be able to withstand wear and tear for another decade or two,” he said.

The civic body, which doesn’t have structural drawings of the bridges, opted for non-destructive testing which showed spalling of concrete (where water enters the structure) and exposure of rebar reinforcement were the most common reasons for the damage. The bridge bearings, under the decking (over which vehicles ply), shifted positions over the years due to vehicle movement and will have to be replaced. “A hydraulic jack will be used to lift the decking and replace the bearings,” he said.

With traffic expected to be hit when the repair work is doen, corporation officials will meet police officers to chalk out a plan. “If everything falls in place, the project can be completed in 18 months. Traffic can be allowed only on one side while work is on at the other side,” the official said.

Tenders have already been floated for the three projects.

While the estimated cost of renovating Parthasarathy bridge is Rs 8 crore, work on the Vaidhyanathan bridge and Captain Cotton Canal bridge is estimated to cost Rs 4.7 crore and Rs 1.7 crore, the official said.

Bridges department officials said that dynamic lighting of flyovers, grade separators, rail over-bridges (ROBs) and the subways , both vehicular and pedestrian, will also begin this year.

Title: Court sends man to gallows for rape and murder of six-year-old Lucknow girl
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: A Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences ( Pocso ) Act court on Friday awarded death sentence to a man for the rape and murder of a six-year-old girl in Lucknow’s Saadatganj area in September last year.Special judge Arvind Mishra said the gruesome rape and murder by Bablu alias Arfaat, fell in the ‘rarest of rare’ category, warranting death penalty.The judge has referred the case file to the high court for confirmation of the death sentence.In his order, the judge observed that Bablu committed the heinous and shameful act, and brutally damaged the private parts of the victim before slitting her throat. Besides, six other injuries were found on the girl’s body. “The convict committed the crime only to satisfy his lust,” the judge said.The court said that Bablu, who lived in Saadatganj and knew the girl, had lured her with toffees on September 15 last year. He took her to his home where he raped her and then slit her throat. “The girl would call the convict ‘mamu’ (maternal uncle). The girl was helpless and could not resist the (muscle) power of the convict. She even did not see the world but the convict made her victim of his lust,” the court observed.“The convict has committed the rape and murder in such a manner that if he is not awarded death penalty, it will have adverse impact on society,” the court said.The prosecution side, represented by additional district government counsel Naveen Tripathi and special public prosecutor Abhisekh Upadhyay, had demanded capital punishment for Bablu.The victim’s father had lodged an FIR against Bablu with Saadatganj police station on the day of the crime.In the FIR, he stated that his daughter went missing on September 15 afternoon. Local residents told him that she was last seen with Bablu. The girl’s father went to Bablu’s home along with police and found his daughter’s body under a bed. Her throat had been slit. She was taken to KGMU trauma centre but was declared brought dead.

Title: 6 carts, 5km, 30minutes: It’s a ‘bull run’ this Pongal at Padi
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Participants of a bullock cart race on a flyover between Padi junction and Kolathur junction, in the wee hours... Read More

CHENNAI: A bullock cart race marked Pongal celebrations on the city outskirts in the early hours of Friday with six such carts participating in the competition organised on Jawaharlal Nehru Road in Padi. The event was held on the arterial road between Padi junction and Kolathur junction.

A Saravanan, one of the organisers of the annual event, said that contestants sped on their bullock carts reaching speeds of 40 km an hour. “The event was held for 30 minutes from 5am to 5.30am. The carts covered the distance of five kilometres within this time,” Saravanan said.

While most of the bullock carts were brought for the event from villages in and around Avadi and Red Hills, some came from Parry’s in the city. Participants on the four wheel carts vied with each other to reach the destination first.

Though bullock cart racing is an annual event, the organisers said that police have been refusing permission for the traditional sport every year.

Saravanan, a farmer hailing from Vellanur village near Avadi in Tiruvallur district, said that the traditional sport has been a part of Pongal festival for several years. Noting that bullock cart race is permitted across the state, he wondered why police were denying permission for a similar event in and around state capital.

For the past three years, bullock cart race is organised along highways on the outskirts of the city.

“The race is part and parcel of Pongal festival,” Saravanan added.

Title: Dist tops in collection from TNSTC Pongal special services
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The Coimbatore region of Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation ( TNSTC ) has earned Rs 3.76 crore from operating special buses during the Pongal season. The district was the highest grosser at Rs 1.38 crore followed by Erode , which accounted for Rs 1.3 crore.

TNSTC had operated a total of 1,781 special buses from Coimbatore, Erode, Tirupur and Nilgiris to various districts across the state, to clear the Pongal rush. Of them, 577 buses were operated from Coimbatore.

The special buses were operated for five days from January 11 to 15. While only 97 buses were operated on the first day, the number of buses went up to 112 on the second day and to 158 on the third day. On January 14, TNSTC introduced a total of 966 buses and the number came down to 380 on the fifth and the final day (January 15). All the special buses were ordinary, non-AC (air-conditioned) town buses.

The special buses benefitted many commuters who were otherwise dependent on private bus operators, who usually hike their rates during the festive season. “Private non-AC seater buses had increased ticket fares to the down south districts to upwards Rs 900,” said G Anuja, a college student in the city. However, TNSTC special buses were available to almost every district from Rs 550 onwards. “It has also become simple to book a ticket online, instead of waiting in queues at the bus stand with uncertainty,” she said.

TNSTC usually operates special buses during festive seasons like Pongal, Diwali, Ayudha Pooja and Tamil New Year. These buses are operated in addition to the 127 buses to Salem from Gandhipuram, and 55 buses to Trichy from Singanallur bus stand. During the festive season, all the buses to the two destinations departed from CODISSIA grounds to reduce congestion in the main bus stands.

Title: How flying ‘terrorists’ have taken western Rajasthan hostage
Content:
28RB village near Indo-Pak border in Sriganganagar.

SRIGANGANAGAR/BIKANER: Locusts have damaged crops across an area of at least 3.6 lakh hectares in 10 districts as western Rajasthan continues to reel under the longest and the worst attack of the pest in 60 years.Swirling swarms of the deadly grasshoppers have eaten up 75% of standing crops in the hardest-hit Sriganganagar district, according to assessments by officials and farmers. The other nine affected districts are Hanumangarh, Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Jodhpur, Jalore, Sirohi, Nagaur and Churu.The first attacks were reported in May last year, when lakhs of pink locusts flying in from southern Pakistan damaged the kharif crop (July-Sept) in the 10 districts. Now, a major wave of fresh attacks have hit the rabi crop (October-March), leaving farmers devastated.Locals in 60 villages of Sriganganagar and Bikaner visited by TOI said the latest attacks began a fortnight ago.Many farmers said the current attack is the biggest ever seen in the region.Among the crops in the line of attack are wheat, gram, mustard, cumin and taramira (arugula). “Locusts are not eating the entire plant but are chewing the flowers, thereby damaging the crop,” said Shyam Somra of 20KYD village in Bikaner district.“Rajasthan witnessed first locust attack in May 2019 and since then, everyone — including the agriculture department, Locust Control Organisation (LCO) and others — has been merely spraying pesticides. This is the biggest-ever attack. Can’t they find out why the attack is still unstoppable and uncontrollable? If breeding is happening in Pakistan, the state administration should urge the Union government to talk to their Pakistani counterparts to control it,” said Subash Sehgal of Kisan Sangarsh Samiti.K L Gurjar, deputy director at LCO-Jodhpur, has been surveying the damage in villages of Sriganganagar and Bikaner districts. “I think the menace is under control in the state, except for Sriganganagar and Jaisalmer districts. A good monsoon, greenery and moisture have been the reasons behind the excessive presence of locusts this year. We have ample pesticides and are checking their movement to control them while they are settled in non-farming areas,” Gurjar told TOI. Farmers alleged that for the last eight months, the state government had neither completed girdawari (cross assessment report), nor had it taken any effective measures to check the swarms of locusts coming at regular intervals.“I have 75 bighas of land and ever since we witnessed fresh locust attack a fortnight ago, we have been spraying pesticides, playing loud music and doing everything to scare away these devils. Government authorities are merely coming and clicking pictures with their mobile phones,” said Soha Lal Bishnoi, a farmer of 12KND village in Sriganganagar.“Almost 1 lakh hectares in Sriganganagar and nearly 2.6-lakh ha in the remaining nine districts have been affected by locust attacks. We have written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and urged his intervention in expediting the relief process. We demand a compensation of Rs 20,000 per acre to each farmer,” said Sehgal.

Title: Tamil Nadu tops in fake Rs 2,000 notes seized in 2018
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Tamil Nadu topped the country in the number of fake Rs 2,000 notes seized as well as in their face value in 2018, National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data showed.Of the 54,776 notes of Rs 2,000 denomination seized across the country in 2018, Tamil Nadu accounted for 12,560 (23%), followed by West Bengal with 9,615 (18%) and Karnataka with 6,750 (12.3%).The National Crime Records Bureau (data shows that one in every five fake notes seized in 2018 was of Rs 2,000 denomination.Experts say that such high seizures, within just two years of the Narendra Modi government deciding on November 8, 2016, to demonetise (ban) Rs 1,000 and Rs 500 notes, have raised many questions about the very objective of the government in curbing circulation of black money and the safety measures claimed to have been taken to strengthen the features of the new note.According to the NCRB report, 2,57,243 fake notes with a face value of Rs 17.95 crore were seized across the country in 2018, with Gujarat reporting the most seizures at 28,855 (face value of Rs 1.23 crore), followed by Tamil Nadu with 24,715 (face value Rs 2.85 crore). Gujarat, despite having a population of 6.04 crore as per Census 2011, reported more number of frauds, compared to Tamil Nadu which had a population of 7.21 crore, according to Census 2011.Among the Union territories, authorities in Delhi seized 67,324 fake notes with a face value of Rs 3.63 crore in 2018, while there were no seizures of such notes in the rest of the UTs, the NCRB reports said.While 54,776 notes of Rs 2,000 denomination (21.3%) were seized, fake notes of old Rs 500 accounted for 14% of the seizures and new Rs 500 notes 10%. The most number of fake notes seized were of Rs 100 denomination, or 33% of the total.In the same period, about 914 FIRs were registered on circulation of fake notes, with the highest recorded in Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal (206) and 72 in Tamil Nadu. A total of 1,002 people were booked for seizure of fake notes with a face value of Rs 17.95 crore, the report said.In terms of face value of the fake notes seized, Tamil Nadu stood second with Rs 2.85 crore, after Delhi at Rs 3.63 crore, the report added.

Title: Cong, CPI & TDP ‘tie up’ in three dists for municipal polls
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Hyderabad: After staying away from each other in the Lok Sabha elections, the Congress , CPI and TDP have come to an informal understanding in elections to municipalities in Khammam, Kothagudem and Suryapet districts.

However, this electoral understanding is not for an entire municipality but depends upon the political equations and winning prospects in wards and divisions of municipalities and municipal corporations.

Congress, CPI and TDP were part of People’s Front (Praja Front) along with TJS that was routed in 2018 Assembly polls. Though the Congress-TDP-CPI-TJS alliance was not disbanded formally after the Assembly polls, the gathbandhan was discontinued with Congress going alone in 2019 Lok Sabha polls. The TDP did not contest the Lok Sabha elections while CPI and CPM forged an alliance and unsuccessfully contested four Lok Sabha seats.

In the elections to be held to about 130 urban local bodies on January 22, the contesting candidates from Congress, CPI and TDP have come to an informal electoral understanding in select wards of various urban local bodies.

For instance, there are 20 wards in Wyra municipality in Khammam district where the Congress is contesting only 10 wards, giving space to TDP which has fielded candidates from 6 wards and CPI from one ward. In Madhira municipality, which has 22 wards, the Congress has fielded just 10 candidates, with TDP fielding 7 candidates, CPI 2 candidates and CPM 3 candidates.

The Congress has already announced that it will go for an electoral understanding at local level with any political party except the TRS and BJP . The CPI too has announced that it would agree for a poll understanding with any party except the BJP.

Title: Seniority issue among SIs: Madras HC upholds state’s decision
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Concluding over a decade-long legal battle between more than 1,300 sub-inspectors (SI) of 1994-95 batch falling under direct recruitment and in-service cadre, in connection with fixation of service seniority, the Madras high court has upheld the decision of the state to place the seniority of 267 in-service candidates above direct recruits, though both were recruited through the same recruitment drive.

“Government thought it fit that those in-service candidates are already aged when compared to the directly recruited candidates and therefore, if they are given preference in fixation of seniority, they could get promotional prospects before their retirement, otherwise they could not. In such view of the matter, we are of the view that the amendments brought to the Special Rules for Tamil Nadu Special Police Subordinate Service is proper and we do not see any reason to interfere with the same,” a division bench of Justices R Subbiah and C Saravanan said.

The issue pertains to a batch of plea moved by 20 sub-inspectors belonging to 1994-95 batch. On January 1, 1994 the Tamil Nadu Uniformed Services Recruitment Board (TNUSRB) issued a notification for selection and appointment of 500 SIs through direct recruitment.

Though departmental candidates were also permitted to apply, most of them became ineligible as the cut-off ages was 30 years. Aggrieved, the in-service candidates moved the erstwhile Tamil Nadu Administrative Tribunal.

Since the tribunal ruled in favour of the departmental candidates, TNSURB earmarked 20% vacancies in the selection for direct recruitment of SIs. Subsequently, the board decided to recruit 1,100 persons as against the proposed 500 posts.

As all the 1,100 candidates cannot be accommodated altogether for training, the recruitment was made in three phases – 500, 600 and 267 (in-service).

After the first batch of 500 were imparted training and absorbed into service, the remaining 600 and 267 were sent for training together. However, as far as, seniority was concerned, in order to give preference to in-service candidates who were appointed against 20% quota, the state fixed them over and above the remaining 600 direct recruits.

Aggrieved, they have approached the court assailing the decision.

Title: Rajasthan locust attack: ‘Pesticides ineffective, make insects only drowsy’
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Plants destroyed by locusts at 13 KND village in Sriganganagar on Friday.

RAISINGHNAGAR/RAVLA: Farmers baffled with the biggest-ever locust attack alleged that Chloro, a pesticide sprayed from the tractor mounted drums in the affected areas by the teams of agriculture and revenue department, is ineffective. They claimed that it merely makes locusts drowsy.

Farmers have demanded to provide them Lambda, a stronger pesticide. However, agriculture experts and officials of Locust Control Organisation (LCO) said that use of Chloro is suitable and environment friendly.

TOI visited several villages in Sriganganagar, Barmer and found that at many villages farmers are spraying the pesticides on their own.

“Chloro se vadiya Lambda hegi, tussi Lambda lao,” said Harjeet Singh Neki, a farmer at 28 RB village near Raisinghnagar while talking to Dr KL Gurjar, deputy director of Locust Control Organisation (LCO).

Farmers said that the pesticide Chloro merely makes the locusts drowsy and within six hours, they again start flying. “We have sprayed Lambda, another pesticide which is very effective and kills the locusts immediately. Why the government is not supplying us this pesticide?,” said Sohan Singh, a native of 25 RB village in Raisinghnagar tehsil of Sriganganagar.

When contacted, Gurjar, said, “Once a locust falls on the ground after the spray, it can never fly and do the damage. Chloro is suitable for them.”

Elaborating more on the issue, Dr GR Matoria, deputy director, agriculture department, Sriganganagar, said, “Lambda and other stronger pesticides are avoided since they can also harm the crop and pests which are actually beneficial for a better yield of crop. It is seen that locusts get stuck onto the crop in the evening, while its wings are moist. This is the time while we use spray and they fall on the ground. In the morning, while they get dried up, they start flying. So, our job is just to stop them from sticking to the crop in the evening to ensure no damage to it.”

Title: Dravidar Viduthalai Kazhagam seeks police action against actor Rajinikanth
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Rajinikanth

COIMBATORE: Functionaries of Dravidar Viduthalai Kazhagam (DVK) on Friday sought action against actor Rajinikanth for his speech against social reformer Periyar.

The functionaries, led by party’s district president M Nehru Das, lodged a police complaint against the actor and demanded that police register an FIR against him under sections 153 (a) (promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony) and 505 (statements conducing to public mischief) of the Indian Penal Code.

While attending the 50th anniversary of Thuglak, a Tamil news magazine, in Salem, the actor had stirred controversy by saying that Periyar had in 1971 taken out a procession after garlanding the images of Lord Ram and Sita with chappals.

The petitioners demanded unconditional apology from the actor for spreading false information about Periyar. “Rajinikanth should apologise for the wrong statement. Otherwise, we will stage protests at all cinema theatres in the district where Rajinikanth ’s Darbar is screened,” said Das. “Party cadre have taken efforts to file petitions seeking legal action against the actor in all districts.”

Acknowledging the complaint, the city police issued receipt of community service register (CSR).

DVK functionaries at Tiruchengode in Namakkal district also filed a police complaint seeking action against the actor on Friday.

Title: Two Palani temple devotees killed as car runs into crowd
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: Two devotees on ‘Patha Yatra’ to Palani temple were killed when a car hit them from behind near Dharapuram in the district on Thursday.

A group of devotees were walking on Uthiyur-Palani Road near Kuttaikadu bus stop around 7pm when a Dharapuram-bound car ran into the crowd, a police officer said.

The car driver has been identified as K Ashok Kumar, 33, of Maravapalayam near Chennimalai of Erode district. The incident resulted in death of Jayaprakash, 17, of Ponnammapettai in Salem, and Kumar, 46, of Modakurichi in Erode. Two other devotees Marichetti, 45, and Gurunathan, 58, both from Pallipalayam in Namakkal district, sustained severe injuries, the officer said.

Police said the driver tried to avoid a truck coming in the opposite direction and he lost control over the vehicle and hit the devotees. Meanwhile, the two injured were taken to the Dharapuram government hospital. The bodies were taken to the hospital for postmortem. The Dharapuram police have registered a case.

Title: Rajasthan: Need to control pink locusts from breeding, say experts
Content:
12KND village near Indo-Pak border in Sriganganagar

13KND village

SRIGANGANAGAR: The Locust Control Organization (LCO) and other experts said that Rajasthan as a whole witnessed the attack of pink locusts which needs to be controlled before they become fit to breed and multiply their numbers.Pink locusts, according to them, is a baby (adult takes yellow colour and is fit for breeding) but it is very lethal for the crops. Experts of LCO, agriculture department and other departments said that since May 2019 when Rajasthan had witnessed its first locust attack in the western Rajasthan, including Barmer and Jaisalmer, there has not been any movement of yellow locusts.“Yellow locust is an adult form and can lay 80 eggs per day while the pink locust is a baby form. Pink locust and its swarms are dangerous. So, we are focusing to control them at this stage only. If they survive and become adults they would be multiplied and it would be very difficult to check their movement,” said Dr KL Gurjar, deputy director, Locust Control Organization (LCO), Jodhpur who is into the control action in 10 affected districts across the state. Camping at Sriganganagar Gurjar along with his team of agriculture experts and others are visiting various affected villages and are following the directions of swarms of the locusts. “In the evening due to excessive moisture their wings get wet and they settle on the tree, farms, forest area and crop area. So, we would be successful if we don’t let them grow as yellow locust. Since May we have not seen any such conversion,” he added.According to experts, it is the winter breeding season for the yellow locusts especially in Pakistan’s Sindh and Balochistan. “Also, pink locusts are immature but are very aggressive in behaviour,” he added.

Title: Jagan asks committee to address farmers’ issues
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Amaravati: The high-power committee comprising ministers and senior officials met chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy on Friday and gave a presentation about their study into the issue of decentralization of administration.

The committee took suggestions from the chief minister and decided to incorporate them in its final report. The committee is scheduled to meet on Saturday to submit the final report to the cabinet. The cabinet will also meet on Saturday.

The committee’s meeting with the CM is significant in the wake of the assembly taking up the issue of three capital cities on January 20.

Minister for municipal administration Botcha Satyanarayana said the government was ready to discuss all issues related to decentralization of administration, capital city and other related issues during the three-day assembly session commencing from Monday.

The minister said the CM has advised the committee to give more thrust to addressing the farmers’ grievances, said Botcha. “The CM directed us to take care of farmers’ grievances. We will make recommendations in such a way that no farmer in the capital city will feel the pinch,” said Botcha.

He said that the committee has more or less agreed to the proposals of the experts’ committees about decentralization of administration as well as development. “TDP is thinking about only 29 villages where as our government is concerned about all the 13 districts, including 29 villages,” said Botcha. He said they would make use of all buildings including the Secretariat structures in Velagapudi. He said they would complete the ongoing structures in Velagapudi and put them to best use

“We will not confront anyone on the issue of the capital city. We are committed to the comprehensive development of the state,” said the minister. He said that they have taken the sentiments and aspirations of people of different regions in the state and working to meet their aspirations.

Botcha appealed to the farmers not to fall prey to Chandrababu Naidu’s designs. He said no one, including local farmers, has asked Naidu why he had failed to issue a notification recognizing Amaravati as the capital city.

He said the government had sympathy for the problems of the farmers and they would address all of them.

Title: PD Act orders till April 15
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Vijayawada: With agitations for Amaravati going on, the government has extended provisions for Preventive Detention Act for another three months. The preventive detention orders issued under the National Security Act 1980 will be enforced across the state including police commissionerates of Vijayawada and Visakhapatnam till April 15.

The government had on October 10 invoked the National Security Act from October 16, 2019 to January 15, 2020. A GO issued on January 14 was extended till April 15. In support of the extension the government cites the letter it received from IGP intelligence.

Anyone likely to act in any manner prejudicial to the security of the state. TNN

Title: Lucknow University departments may soon have own YouTube channels
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: Soon, all 43 departments of LU may have their own YouTube channels, where professors will upload lectures, tutorials and other academic-related videos. The move will help in making Lucknow University a brand. This was the suggestion given by LU’s vice-chancellor prof Alok Kumar Rai during his first official interaction with faculty members at Malviya Hall on Friday.

“Also, every faculty should adopt one student and sponsor his/her education in best possible way,” said Rai. The main focus, he added, will be to make LU a student-centric system for which every faculty should at least reserve one hour exclusively for students so that they can get faculty’s support in solving any personal, professional or academics related issue.

“We have a Padmashri professor and several others of national and international repute, our 43 departments should make lectures of such professors available online via YouTube channel , this will help in making LU a brand ,” said the V-C.

He said university holds an excellent academic record and despite running primarily traditional and conventional courses still it has highest citation in reputed journals like SCOPUS and Web of Science. The citation index of the LU is higher than several notable central universities.

The V-C asked professors to focus more on research and every faculty of the university should have atleast two research scholars and a project work.

He also shared that with the focus to give a technological boost to the university’s academic functioning soon facilities like a digital locker—availability of the academic document online and use of smart classes for learning and video making will be mobilized.

All professors were also asked to assure flag hoisting at respective departments and hostels during Republic and Independence Day.

Title: P Sabitha Indra Reddy and Dharmana Prasada Rao appear before CBI court
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Telangana cabinet minister for school education P Sabitha Indra Reddy and former minister Darmana Prasad (extr... Read More

HYDERABAD: Telangana education minister P Sabitha Indra Reddy , AP’s former revenue minister Dharmana Prasada Rao , IAS officer Y Srilakshmi, mines and geology former director V D Rajagopal, former principal secretary of revenue department M Samuel and several revenue officials of Anantapur district appeared before a special CBI court in Hyderabad on Friday.

They were all named accused in the CBI’s supplementary charge sheet in the Penna Cements episode of the quid pro quo case filed against AP chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy .

They appeared before the court in tune with an order passed by principal special judge B R Madhusudan Rao of CBI courts who, last week, directed them to appear before him while taking cognisance of the the supplementary charge sheet. Special judge B R Madhusudan Rao is in charge of both CBI as well as the ED courts.

CBI’s charge against the accused was that they had all conspired to help Penna Cements to secure allotments of land, limestone mines, concessions pertaining to setting up of a five star hotel in Hyderabad etc. In return, Penna Cements chairman P Pratap Reddy had invested money in Jaganmohan Reddy ’s firms, CBI said while describing this as a quid pro quo arrangement.

The case was posted to January 24 for further hearing.

Title: 2 women farmhands killed in tractor accident, 7 hurt
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Vijayawada: Two persons died on the spot while seven others suffered ghastly injuries in a tractor accident at Jonnalagadda in Nandigama mandal of Krishna district on Friday morning. The deceased were identified as G Triveni and V Nagamani – both farm labourers.

According to Nandigama Town sub-inspector Hari Babu, the incident happened around 8.15 am when they were ferrying nine farm labourers to Damluru village for work. The speeding tractor lost control when the driver applied brakes at a sharp turn, causing the vehicle to crash sideways.

Two persons fell down and were crushed under the trolley. Locals alerted police who rushed to the spot and moved the victims to Nandigama Government Hospital in the town. Cops said one more person was identified as critical and receiving treatment. Preliminary investigation revealed that the tractor was overcrowded which was the main reason for the mishap as it resulted in the vehicle losing its balance and crashing sideways. Sources told TOI there was poor visibility in the area at the time of the accident due to heavy fog. Meanwhile, both Triveni and Nagamani’s bodies were taken to a local government hospital for post-mortem and later handed over to family members for final rights.

Cops said that both of them were married and are survived by their husbands and two children each.

A case under section 304A of IPC (causing death due to negligence) was registered at Nandigama town police station.

Title: Photos: Drum beats, DJ music scare away locusts in Rajasthan
Content:
A woman beats a steel plate at 64NP village in Sriganganagar to drive away locusts on Friday.

A farmer beats a steel plate at 64NP village in Sriganganagar to drive away locusts on Friday.

SRIGANGANAGAR: The farmers are having sleepless nights since the arrival of locusts in Sriganganagar . But they have taken things to their own hands and trying their best to curb the menace.From child to old man in a family, everybody is engaged in dealing with the pests. They are beating drums, playing loud DJ music to scare insects away.“Raat ko paani lagatey hain aur din main tiddi bhagatey hain (During the night, we water our crops and during the day, we scare away locusts),” said Suresh Godara, a native of 14 KND village near Ravla tehsil of Sriganganagar district.At some of the villages, the farmers get upset and start crying in apprehension. “Rs 3 lakh loan liyedo hai bank se tiddi kha gi to ke bachsi (I have taken loan from the bank. If locusts eat our crop what will be left),” said Mohammed Noor a native of 18 KND village near Ravla.Since the famers get irrigation water in irregular intervals, they are already troubled during winters. “In the evening, when locusts get onto the mustard crop, we start beating the utensils, step up accelerator of parked trackers and make various sounds to scare them away. For the past fortnight, we are living in fear,” said Harnam Singh Neeta, a native of 63 NP village near Raisinghnagar tehsil of Sriganganagar district.Some of the farmers are also bursting firecrackers.Farmers in Sriganganagar have also created whatsApp groups to share the movement of locusts and their fear too.“In these groups, we are getting regular updates on the movement of locusts. In some of the groups, we have added local patwari, tehsildar so that they may also get an idea about locusts,” said Vikrant Godara, a farmer at 13 KND village.

Title: YS Jagan quid pro quo case: Court to hear CBI and ED cases jointly
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Jaganmohan reddy at CBI court in Hyderabad on January 10 in the quid pro quo investment cases. (PTI photo)

HYDERABAD: Special judge B R Madhusudan Rao of the ED court on Friday dismissed an application filed by YS Jaganmohan Reddy and his associates urging the ED court to defer the trial under prevention of money laundering Act (PMLA) till CBI court concludes its trial in the same quid pro quo case.

Jagan’s contention is that if the alleged original crime is proved in a CBI court, then the question of trying the accused for acquiring proceeds of crime would arise and not prior to that. Conducting trial in both cases simultaneously would be unfair to the parties involved, his counsel argued. ED’s counsel T V Subba Rao opposed this line of argument and said that PMLA court is a special court which has the mandate to try both the cases jointly under Section 44 of the PMLA.

The judge also dismissed the plea of Jagan and other accused seeking a joint hearing of the discharge pleas filed by several accused.

He agreed with CBI counsel K Surender’s contention that all the 11 chargesheets in the case deal with distinct and separate crimes, though emanated from a single FIR. The CBI counsel said that discharge petitions filed by accused should be dealt with separately.

Title: Tamil Nadu: RPF to use dogs to sniff out wildlife contraband
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Two RPF handlers and a dog at Police Training School (Dogs), Bhopal

CHENNAI: For the first time, the Railway Protection Force (RPF) will be using trained dogs to track and detect wildlife being smuggled through the railway network. The dogs are currently undergoing a drill at the Police Training School (Dogs), Bhopal, under TRAFFIC and WWF-India’s pioneer wildlife sniffer dog training programme, ‘Super Sniffers’.

“This is the first time we are training sniffer dogs for the RPF. We have seen that in the north and a few other areas railway network is being used to smuggle wildlife products,” says Dr Saket Badola, head of TRAFFIC, a wildlife trade monitoring network, adding the training for the two dog squads – each consisting of one dog and two handlers began a couple of months ago. “They are being trained for the northern and eastern regions of Indian Railways. The training will be completed by June.”

The RPF is responsible for the protection and security of Indian Railways, considered the fourth largest railway network in the world by size. The network is often being used to smuggle illegal wildlife products within the country and to border areas for cross-border trafficking. To help curb this illicit trade of protected and endangered wildlife species, RPF is now planning to use sniffer dogs.

“We have seen many cases where wildlife is smuggled interstate by rail,” says A K Kunnu, assistant commissioner, RPF, eastern region.

“Since the eastern zone is adjacent to countries like Bangladesh, we have seen that several species of tortoises and snakes are also being trafficked by rail. Employing sniffer dogs will help us detect such illegal transport better.”

TRAFFIC’s ‘Super Sniffers’ programme was launched in 2008 in India. “Earlier, we had sniffer dogs to detect narcotics and arms but not for wildlife products,” says Dr Badola. “We usually invite enforcement agencies such as the forest department to collaborate with us. Once they show interest, we get in touch with national-level dog training institutes to design with them a training curriculum focussed on combating trafficking in wildlife products.”

The programme covers sniffing, searching, tracking, and general obedience training of dogs. “We procure pups from a recognised kennel,” says Dr Badola, adding two breeds German shepherd and Belgian malinois are popularly used as they are the best at sniffing and tracking. “Conan, the dog that was used to track Islamic State founder and chief Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, was a Belgian malinois,” adds Dr Badola.

Under the TRAFFIC’s programme, 66 sniffer dogs have been trained so far. “We have worked with about 19 states, including Tamil Nadu . “While we arrange for procurement of pups and training, the agencies working with us, assign two of their staff members designated as handlers and assistant handlers, who are responsible for their use and upkeep after their deployment in field. These staff members also undergo the rigorous nine-month-long training along with the dogs” says Dr Badola.

According to him, more dogs will be trained for RPF in the future.

“These two squads will be deployed in the northern and the eastern regions. This is a pilot programme and considering the interest shown, we will be training more dogs for RPF for different regions across the country,” says Dr Badola.

Title: Tamil Nadu records seven tiger deaths last year, up from three in 2017
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Mudumalai Tiger Reserve in Nilgiris recorded the highest of three deaths while Sathayamangalam, the youngest t... Read More

COIMBATORE: While tiger deaths are coming down across the country, Tamil Nadu recorded a rise in the big cat mortality.

In 2019, the country saw tiger deaths drop to 95, from 115 in 2017, with Madhya Pradesh topping the chart at 31 deaths. But Tamil Nadu, home to four tiger reserves, reported an increase from three tiger deaths in 2017 to six in 2018 and seven in 2019.

Mudumalai Tiger Reserve in Nilgiris recorded the highest of three deaths while Sathayamangalam, the youngest tiger reserve recorded one. Three other deaths were reported outside the tiger reserves in the jungles of Megamalai and Nilgiris.

Forest officials say there was nothing to be worried about the phenomena. For one, the tiger deaths in Tamil Nadu were not due to poaching and were due to natural causes and territorial fighting among the species. Besides, there was an increase in tiger population in the state and it was normal for death rate to spike corresponding to the rise in births.

“If the mortality is due to an unnatural or man–induced cause, then there is something to worry about. But in the last four years there was no such untoward incidents reported in the state,’’ said Anurag Mishra, additional principal chief conservator of forests, Project Tiger , Tamil Nadu.

Forest officials say that the seven deaths reported in the state last year were due to natural causes according to preliminary examination. There was no instance of teeth or nail of the animals missing, as in the case of poaching. There was nothing to suggest poisoning too. However, forest officials treat the deaths as suspicious until forensic reports come in ruling out unnatural causes of death.

“The one death that occurred in Sathyamangalam was due to territorial fighting between two tigers,’’ said Arun Lal, deputy director of Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve.

Environmentalists point out that the increase in tiger population calls for additional measures. According to the latest tiger census, the big cat population appears to thrive in the state’s forests rising by leaps from 76 in 2006 to 264 in 2018.

“Tiger is a territorial animal. When the population surges beyond the holding capacity of a tiger reserve, they tend to stray out of the reserves. That could be the reason for three deaths outside the tiger reserves,’’ said environmentalist Osai Kalidas. He said tigers used to venture from Mudumalai and Bandipur tiger sanctuaries into Sathyamangalam forests ten years ago when latter was not a sanctuary. Eventually, Sathyamangalam was declared a tiger reserve. “The point is, the tiger reserves get additional funds and heightened vigil whereas those out of the reserves don’t get that. The government should provide the similar attention to these areas abutting tiger reserves,’’ he said.

Title: Manikonda’s cup of water woes overflow
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Hyderabad: Residents of Manikonda expressed their angst over the lack of amenities ahead of municipal polls at a meet on Friday. Representatives from political parties as well as residential welfare associations attended the meet.

Highlighting the issue of encroachments was Dr P Avinash, president, Tirumala Hills Residential Welfare Association, Puppalaguda. “A park of 6,050 square yards is being encroached upon by land grabbers and officials have turned a blind eye to it. The encroacher is now trying to sell this land which must be protected. It is part of the HMDA approved layout.”

Kantha Rao of Sriramnagar Colony Resident Welfare Association also talked about land grabbing. “Nearly three acres of government land is under threat. With prices soaring in the area, safeguarding public spaces has become a huge problem.” He also asked that work on a community hall — which has been halted — be finished.

At the face-to-face programme, the main concern however remained the lack of water supply to the area. Sitaram Dulipala, president, Federation of All Colonies’ Residents Welfare Associations, said, “Water remains the key issue. All the colonies in Manikonda are facing a severe water crisis, especially during the summers.”

Responding to the concerns, Narender Reddy, former sarpanch and a BJP candidate, said, “Officials have asked residents to bear 50% of the cost for laying pipelines which is unfair. The funds from the municipality itself are enough to address the water issue.”

TRS representative P Jangaiah said, “Our MLA has spoken to the CM on the water issue. I have been helping two colonies myself by providing water and will continue to ensure they get it even after the elections.”

Title: Sikh museum to come up in Agra
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Lucknow: A museum dedicated to the Sikh religion will soon be coming up in Agra. The museum, dedicated to Guru Nanak on his 550th birth anniversary, will highlight the cultural, historical and art associated with Sikhism and seek to educate the younger generation about the history of the religion.

RS Bagga, president of Lucknow Gurudwara Prabandhak Committee, told TOI that the project will be executed by the Centre and is likely to come up on an area of 5 acre. “If government land is acquired then the cost of the project will be Rs 10 crore and if private land is acquired, Rs 5 crore will be spent. The proposal was floated by our committee during the 550th birth anniversary celebrations of Guru Nanak in November 2019 and chief minister Yogi Adityanath agreed to it immediately,” he said.

At a meeting chaired by principal secretary culture Jitendra Kumar recently, Lucknow was among the two cities being considered for the project but Agra won due to its proximity to both the state and national capital. Bagga said Agra was also important as Guru Teg Bahadur and his three aides had been arrested by Aurangzeb from the city and it is an important place of pilgrimage for Sikhs.

The museum and research centre will focus on generating awareness about the Sikh religion and highlighting art and craft, culture and history associated with it. Part of the project would be to identify contribution of Sikh films, music, art, science to India, identification of important sites linked with Sikhim and their beautification and promotion.

Title: 13th century Vishnu idol found lying outside temple restored
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Vijayawada: Cultural Centre of Vijayawada and Amaravati (CCVA) restored a 13th century Lord Vishnu idol that was neglected outside the Motupalli temple in Prakasam district on Friday.

CEO of CCVA E Sivanagi Reddy said they received information about the artefact lying uncared from Ravi Ramanatha Babu, chairman, District Cooperative Marketing Society, Prakasam.

Reddy said that they surveyed around the temple and found a headless torso of a Vishnu sculpture which is in the ‘Prasanna Keshava’ form. They also found a stone inscription of Kakatiya Ganapati Deva, which records gift of some land to God Prasanna Keshava at Motupalli. “These sculptures are datable to the period between 13th to 16 century AD,” Reddy told TOI. Reddy said that during the brisk trade activity at the port town right from 1st century BC to 16th century AD, there were a good number of bronzes, coins of the Chola and Chinese affiliation were recovered from excavations.

The local people stated that they have given requests to the government to develop the neglected temple as it can establish an economy of its own for them.

Title: Gang stabs kabaadi player for including guest players in team, one imprisoned
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Coimbatore: A kabaadi contest that was conducted near New Dhamu Nagar in Ammankulam here as part of Pongal celebrations took an ugly turn when a three-member gang stabbed a 23-year-old player for inducting guest players into his team on Thursday night. The injured player is battling for life at the intensive care unit of the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH). The Ramanathapuram police on Friday arrested one of the gang members in connection with the incident.

Police identified the victim as K Naveenkumar, of Slum Clearance Board Colony at Ammankulam. He has more than four assault and ganja peddling cases pending against him with the Race Course, Ramanathapuram and Saibaba Colony police stations.

An investigation officer said the match was organized by a section of youths from Ammankulam. “Naveenkumar included three guest players in his team and bagged the first prize.”

After the match, Naveenkumar and one of the guest players - Logeshwaran, 26, of Highways Colony on Trichy Road - went to New Dhambu Nagar to freshen up. Suddenly, R Vijayakumar, 23, of Rajivgandhi Street at Nehru Nagar in Vadavalli, his younger brother R Kannan, 21, and his friend A Hariharan, 21, of Jothipuram near Periyanaickenpalayam waylaid the duo and scolded Naveenkumar for preferring guest players to local youths.

“As they entered into a heated argument, Vijayakumar pulled out a knife from his pant pocket and stabbed Naveenkumar on his chest and abdomen five times. Logeshwaran also suffered a stab injury to on his hand while trying to save his friend. The gang fled immediately after attacking the duo,” the officer said.

Logeshwaran, meanwhile, rushed Naveenkumar to CMCH. Based on Naveenkumar’s complaint, the Ramanathapuram police registered a case against the trio under Sections 307 (attempt to murder) and 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 75 (i) (c ) of the Tamil Nadu City Police (TNCP) Act and arrested Vijayakumar on Friday. He was later lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

“Vijayakumar is facing more than five assault and ganja peddling cases in the city. We have formed a team to nab the remaining two, who are on the run,” the officer said.

Title: Mayawati's decision on Lok Sabha leader irks BSP man
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

BSP chief Mayawati

LUCKNOW: BSP chief Mayawati ’s decision to replace Danish Ali with first-time MP Ritesh Pandey as leader of the party in the Lok Sabha has not been received well in the party.

The change, made ostensibly because a Muslim (Munqad Ali) is already UP BSP chief, and Mayawati wanted social equilibrium, has been questioned openly by former bureaucrat and party member Fateh Bahadur Singh.

In a series of tweets, Singh, who served as principal secretary in the CM office and of home under Mayawati and joined the party in 2017, said: “Leaders of the party in both Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha from the same community (Brahmin) symbolises what? Is it according to BSP’s idea of social change? Did Kanshiram found BSP to achieve this goal? The bahujan samaj wants to know.”

Singh confirmed to TOI that he had raised these issues on social media and these were “genuine concerns”. On Twitter, he added that in the past eight months since the current Lok Sabha members had been elected, BSP had changed its leader of the House five times “in the name of social equilibrium”.

Asked about his statement on Twitter, Singh said he was not questioning Mayawati’s decision but just expressing his worry. “Is the current leadership trying to achieve the goal set by Kanshiram when he formed the party? Will bahujan samaj get social, economic and political rights? Will social transformation take place? Bahujans will have to think about this,” he said.

A similar concern has been raised by several others in the party, though nobody would speak out openly. Sources in BSP said Singh currently does not hold any post in the party and was free to air his opinion. “Others too have questioned the idea behind this social equilibrium. If two Muslims are not acceptable, how are two Brahmins in high positions?” asked a senior party member.

So far, four people have headed BSP in the Lok Sabha since May 2019.

Title: Coimbatore: Night prowler keeps residents on tenterhooks
Content:
CCTV footage shows man parking his motorcycle near the home, jumping over the compound wall and opening a wind... Read More

Watch: A bike-borne man jumps over the coumpound wall of a house at #Edayarpalayam on Thadagam Road #Coimbatore https://t.co/SupjmGYWxS — TOI Coimbatore (@TOI_Coimbatore) 1579322721000

COIMBATORE: The city police are on the lookout for a motorcycle-borne miscreant, who has been caught on camera peeping in the windows of homes at Edayarpalayam on Thadagam Road, under the cover of darkness.Police formed a special team to nab the man after CCTV camera footage showing him opening bedroom windows went viral on social media on Friday. The man, said to be 40 years old, was seen roaming on Marudham Nagar, Bharathi Colony, Poombukar Nagar, Kurinji Nagar, Mullai Nagar and Kavundampalayam.A CCTV footage collected from a home at Marudham Nagar last Monday shows him parking his motorcycle near the home, jumping over the compound wall and opening a window on the ground floor. He tries to look inside before leaving the place in a hurry.“The man did not steal anything from the houses. We don’t know why he opened the windows. People are afraid after the videos went viral,” said a resident of Marudham Nagar.Edayarpalayam Marudham Nagar Residents Welfare Association president N Govindarajan has lodged a complaint with Thudiyalur police inspector Balamurali Sundaram. “The playground in the area has become a virtual den for unsocial elements. Women are afraid to venture out after several chain-snatching incidents were reported from the area,” he said.Police have tightened night patrolling in the area, inspector Sundaram said.In Video: Coimbatore: Night prowler leaves residents in fear

Title: Tamil Nadu: Chinna Thambi grabs eyeballs at Top Slip ‘Elephant Pongal’
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

On Friday, 20 elephants including 23-year-old Chinna Thambi were taken to Top Slip from Kozhikamuthi elephant ... Read More

COIMBATORE: While bulls were rearing at the arena amidst tamers in Palamedu and Alanganallur jallikattu, the forest department of Coimbatore division celebrated ‘ Elephant Pongal ’ near Top Slip in the Anaimalai Tiger Reserve on Friday. Twenty trained elephants, including Chinna Thambi , the crop raiding tusker which was captured from Thadagam Valley last year, participated in the celebration.

To create awareness and explain about the importance of elephants among the tourists, the forest department used to celebrate ‘Elephant Pongal’ at Top Slip every year. On Friday, 20 elephants including the 23-year-old Chinna Thambi were taken to Top Slip from Kozhikamuthi elephant camp by walk and all the 20 elephants including four kumki elephants were decorated by mahouts. All the 20 elephants were lined up on the grasslands at the entrance of the Top Slip. Kumkum, sandal paste, and holy ash were smeared on the elephants’ foreheads and kumki ‘Kaleem’ led the herd of trained elephants.

District forest officer of Pollachi forest division S Marimuthu provided sweet Pongal to the elephants. Later, banana, coconut and sugarcane were also given to the elephants by the forest department officials.

Range officer of Top Slip forest range P Sakthivel said, “Five days ago, Chinna Thambi was taken to Kozhikamuthi elephant camp from Varakaliar camp and we monitored the behaviour of Chinna Thambi at the camp. Then only, we brought the elephant to Top Slip where Chinna Thambi participated in the celebrations.”

After the celebrations, all the 20 trained elephants were taken to Kozhikamuthi elephant camp from Top Slip.

Thousands of tourists visited Top Slip on Friday to see the ‘Elephant Pongal’ celebrations.

Title: Guntur man stabs rival steel trader
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Vijayawada: A 70-year-old steel trader was murdered by his rival over a business dispute in the capital region of Amaravati in Guntur district on Friday.

The deceased was identified as Sheikh Hussein (70). According to Krosuru Police, the accused, Sheikh Babavali, and Hussein have been rivals in business for several years in the past and run their businesses in shops adjacent to each other. Police said that they had a heated argument with each accusing the other of trying to destroy his business.

Babavali visited Hussein’s shop on Friday carrying a knife. In a fit of rage, Babavali stabbed Hussein multiple times and fled from the spot. Soon, fellow workers and locals rushed to his aid and called an ambulance. The accused is absconding. TNN

Title: Nizampet: A bustling place with no basic amenities
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Land prices are soaring and construction of new buildings is going on at a rapid pace in Nizampet . This should mean the area is thriving. However, lanes and by-lanes of colonies here are dotted with to-let boards. The main reason: Acute shortage of water, which pushes monthly water charges over Rs 5,000.This results in a cut down on rents and difficulty in finding tenants as well as buyers. Deteriorating level of air quality only makes matters worse say residents. While locals are weighing in their options ahead of the municipal elections, they point out the issues they want to be resolved at the earliest.In fact, many colonies in Nizampet also witness a deluge — triggered due to encroachment of lakes — every year. Owners in the affected parts are on the lookout to sell off or rent out their properties. P Ramesh, from Srinivasa Nagar Colony, said: “I have been trying to sell this house for the past two years, but have been unable to find a buyer. While tenants are available, I get Rs 6,000 for a two bedroom apartment. Because the building gets a daily supply of tanker water, it results in a monthly charge of Rs 4,000-Rs 5,000 depending on the season. The municipal water supply is only there for an hour here, which clearly isn’t enough.”Although several other house owners admit to the issues, they cite other reasons for moving out of the area. Apart from water woes, air pollution is a big problem. Stench of pollutants released by industries in neighbouring areas force residents to keep doors and windows closed for a good part of the day. The ones heading out frequently complain of breathing problems.Jagdish Babu, a resident of Reddy Avenue Colony in Nizampet, said: “Every day, morning or evening, there is a stench strong enough to give a headache to most people. It gets worse for children and the elderly. Also, there isn’t a single park for recreational activity in the area despite of having over one lakh people living here.”Problems for residents are compounded by the continuous construction activity in the area, which gives rise to loads of dust throughout the day. Amid the entire huge commercial bustle in this developing area, there is hardly any greenery to counter the impact of pollution. “If you look around, you can see dust rising all through the day,” BN Sridhar, a shop-owner near Ambedkar Statue Junction. “No matter how many times one cleans the place, there is always a thick sheet of white dust. Many a times, it drives away customers.”Condition of the road is also a huge problem. Potholes and partially filled up stretches, dug up previously, can be seen everywhere. “After driving through such precarious roads, coming back to a pollution filled and waterless house is a big issue. Most vacant houses are put on rent and tenants keep moving out frequently. Even with tanker supply, it’s a headache every second day when the tanker gets delayed, and the entire day goes for a toss, delaying daily work,” said a tenant in Sri Sai Nagar.

Title: Suspects in cop murder case booked under UAPA
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

KANYAKUMARI/COIMBATORE: Abdul Shameem and Thoufiq, who were arrested in connection with the murder of special sub-inspector (SSI) of police Y Wilson, 57, at Kaliyakkavilai checkpost on the inter-state border in Kanyakumari district on January 8, have been booked under sections of The Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act ( UAPA ).

Superintendent of police (SP) of Kanyakumari district N Sreenath said they were booked under three Sections – 13 (punishment for unlawful activities), 18 (punishment for conspiracy, etc.) and 20 (punishment for being member of a terrorist gang or organisation) – of the UAPA for operating against the country.

Earlier, the Kaliyakkavilai police booked the duo under Sections 302 (punishment for murder) and 506(ii) (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and Sections 7 read with 25(1A) and 25(1B) of the Arms Act for illegal possession of the weapon that was used in the murder.

Police said they were not booked under UAPA earlier as they were yet to ascertain their terror links. Following their arrest and investigation, they have been booked under UAPA also. Police said they will move the Kuzhithurai court in Kanyakumari district on Monday, seeking police custody of the duo.

Meanwhile, the national investigation agency (NIA) is all set to take over investigation from the Tamil Nadu police, as the case has been altered to UAPA. “Kanyakumari district police is continuing investigation and will be taking the accused into custody for interrogation. NIA officials will visit Kaliyakkavilai soon and will take up the case for further investigation within a month,” said a source.

“We will conduct preliminary inquiry with the arrested duo and will send a report to the ministry of home affairs (MHA). In the report, we will mention the gravity of the case. After getting order from the MHA, we would take up the case for further investigation on the role of the two Islamic State (IS) cadres in the murder of SSI Wilson,” said an NIA source.

The source added that the investigation agency has to file a chargesheet against the arrested people who were booked under UAPA, within 180 days. “We would file a chargesheet before the special court for NIA cases at Poonamallee in Chennai. The electronic gadgets seized from the arrested people will be sent to forensic laboratory for further investigation,” the source said.

Title: UP BJP chief: Teach a lesson to critics of ‘Bharat Mata’
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

UP BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh after his re-election with CM Yogi Adityanath on Friday

LUCKNOW: Seeking to raise nationalist pitch, UP BJP chief Swatantra Dev Singh on Friday said those who demean ‘Bharat Mata’ should be taught a lesson.

Talking to party workers after being reelected as UP BJP chief, Singh said, “Bharat Mata ke khilaf agar koi ek shabd bhi bola to uski zuban kheench li jayegi...”

Talking to TOI, Singh later clarified that he meant to say that party workers should teach a lesson to those who demean the country. “Party workers should have a cool mind and take party forward,” he added.

Singh was the only BJP leader to file nomination for the post of UP BJP president and his reelection was announced by BJP national general secretary Bhupendra Yadav in the presence of UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath at party headquarters.

“I will not hesitate to give my blood for a worker who toils to take the party ahead. This is not the time to lead a luxurious life but to work harder. A party worker should not be disappointed if he or she does not get a post. Posts of party leaders keep changing,” he said.

“Party workers may get angry with me but not with ‘Kamal’ (BJP’s election symbol) as it would amount to cheating the country,” Singh said. Mounting an attack on Congress, Samajwadi Party and Bahujan Samaj Party for calling RSS, the ideological fountainhead of BJP, a ‘Hindutva terror organization’, Singh said RSS was a pavitra (pious) organisation which gave seers to the country. “It is rather the opposition which is neck deep in corruption,” he said.

Speaking on the occasion, CM Yogi said: “I hope that the BJP organisation will become stronger and more aggressive and help the party to achieve 3/4th majority in 2022 assembly elections.” “The present generation is lucky to see BJP moving to the top. Many generations of BJP leaders have struggled for this,” he said.

Title: Chennai: Railway food stall shut over hygiene concerns
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Screengrabs of a video posted by a rail passenger on Twitter showed a vendor at the food stall on platform 7 o... Read More

CHENNAI: Southern Railway officials have ordered a probe to check if workers at a food stall on Platform 7 at the Egmore station used water from the hydrant on railway tracks to prepare tea/ milk.

The action came after a video shot by a passenger, showing the stall worker fill a tea kettle with water from the hydrant, went viral on social media over the past two days. This led to users posting on social media that the water, sent to the toilets of trains, was being used to adulterate milk used for making tea and coffee.

On Friday evening, the divisional railway manager of Chennai tweeted that the stall was closed immediately pending an investigation. The tweet also clarified that the salesman had used the water only to refill the outer wall of a double-walled electric milk boiler and not for diluting the milk.

A senior official told TOI that rumours of ‘toilet water’ being used to make tea and coffee at railway stalls were false.

“The salesman seen in the video is filling water from the hydrant, which is supplied by Chennai Metrowater Supply and Sewerage Board (CMWSSB). The same water is available in taps at stations as well,” the official clarified. However, the water cannot be used for mixing with water as it contains chlorine and that it would instantly spoil the milk.

“The water was being used only for the external jacket in the boiler that keeps the milk or tea warm,” the official explained.

For food preparation, only RO water sourced from cans should be used by licensees, the official said. “We conduct periodic checks to ensure there is no drop in quality,” the official said.

However, the official said there were shortcomings in the work habits of catering staff at these stalls. “We have instructed them to avoid such (filling water from hydrant) practices as the public will perceive this as wrong. But in this case, the salesman was lazy and did not go up to the tap to fill water,” he said.

It was the only stall on Platform 7 at Egmore station and ultimately, the passengers would stand to lose by its closure, he said.

Title: Mayoral polls: BJP pins hopes on GTD’s supporters to back party
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

BJP

MYSURU: BJP, which is at the helm in the state, is leaving no stone unturned to capture power at the Mysuru City Corporation (MCC) despite the opposition — Congress and JD(S) — coming together to jointly fight the upcoming mayoral polls. Even though BJP functionaries are publicly stating that they are ready to sit in the opposition, they are working behind the scenes to engineer defections from JD(S).

As the election for the pivotal posts is scheduled on Saturday, both Congress and JD(S) have shifted their corportors to separate resorts on the outskirts of the city fearing poaching from BJP. They will be ferried directly from the resort to the council hall on the day of election.

However, BJP’s confidence seems to stem from the fact that former minister and JD(S) leader GT Devegowda has distanced himself from the party and moved closer to BJP. The saffron party leaders are hoping that Gowda’s supporters in the JD(S) will revolt and support BJP in mayoral polls.

Speaking to TOI, a JD(S) corporator, who is housed in the resort, said that the party high command fears that Devegowda may influence his supporters during the election.

“So the party has issued a whip to its corporators and warned action if they go against the party’s decision and involve in cross voting. The corporators, especially those who are close to Devegowda, are being watched closely,” the corporator said.

JD(S) MLA SR Mahesh, who visited the resort on Friday, asked the party corporators, who are being lodged from past two days, to stay together and work as per the direction of the high command.

“Earlier GT Devegowda was in charge of the district. But now he has decided to remain neutral. The party has instructed me to manage the election,” he said.

While sources in BJP said that they will adopt wait and watch strategy. “Till now we have not decided anything regarding trying to come to power with support from corporators from opposition parties. The leaders will discuss and take a decision,” said BJP city president BS Manjunath.

Title: Gang stabbed kabaadi player in Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A kabaadi contest that was conducted near New Dhamu Nagar in Ammankulam here as part of Pongal celebrations took an ugly turn when a three-member gang stabbed a 23-year-old player for inducting guest players into his team on Thursday night.

The injured player is battling for life at the intensive care unit of the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH). The Ramanathapuram police on Friday arrested one of the gang members in connection with the incident.

Police identified the victim as K Naveenkumar, of Slum Clearance Board Colony at Ammankulam. He has more than four assault and ganja peddling cases pending against him with the Race Course, Ramanathapuram and Saibaba Colony police stations.

An investigation officer said the match was organized by a section of youths from Ammankulam. “Naveenkumar included three guest players in his team and bagged the first prize.”

After the match, Naveenkumar and one of the guest players - Logeshwaran, 26, of Highways Colony on Trichy Road - went to New Dhambu Nagar to freshen up. Suddenly, R Vijayakumar, 23, of Rajivgandhi Street at Nehru Nagar in Vadavalli, his younger brother R Kannan, 21, and his friend A Hariharan, 21, of Jothipuram near Periyanaickenpalayam waylaid the duo and scolded Naveenkumar for preferring guest players to local youths.

“As they entered into a heated argument, Vijayakumar pulled out a knife from his pant pocket and stabbed Naveenkumar on his chest and abdomen five times. Logeshwaran also suffered a stab injury to on his hand while trying to save his friend. The gang fled immediately after attacking the duo,” the officer said.

Logeshwaran, meanwhile, rushed Naveenkumar to CMCH.
