Kolkata: An elevated Circular Railway track between Kolkata airport and Dum Dum, which has been lying unused for nearly four years, is finally being dismantled to pave way for widening of Jessore Road and construction of a proposed flyover between Kaikhali on VIP Road and Airport gate 2 on Jessore Road.

Work for the dismantling of the viaduct had begun three weeks back and on Friday, TOI found a crane blocking a portion of Jessore Road towards Nagerbazar, pulling down viaducts one by one, at the airport gate 1 crossing. Once all the viaducts are pulled down, the authorities will raze the pillars.

“Since the track has already been abandoned and with an Metro line running right under the area, the structure had become a safety hazard. Hence, it is being pulled down to create space for road traffic,” said Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee. Another official added: “The structure has been eating up a major part of the thoroughfare for years and is an obstruction for future projects, like the proposed flyover connecting VIP Road with Jessore Road.”

The elevated structure was part of Circular Railway’s extension from Dum Dum Cantonment to Biman Bandar station, passing through Jessop, Jessore Road and VIP Road. The service was inaugurated by the then railway minister, Lalu Prasad Yadav, in July, 2006. However, a variety of reasons — from poor patronage and odd train timings to the elevated station and its distance from the terminal building — resulted in shutting down the service four years ago, with the Biman Bandar station closing down in September 2016.

However, long before the services had stopped, the Biman Bandar station had become a ghost station with just two trains in the day and a handful of passengers availing the services. In 2009, Metro Rail had proposed to convert the ill-conceived suburban rail service into a Metro Railway connection. But the idea was scrapped and now, even as Metro train will run on elevated tracks till Jessore Road, it will go underground to enter the Airport station, where work is already under way to convert it into a junction where lines from New Garia, Barasat and Noapara will converge. Along with the station, there will be an underground yard with basic maintenance facilities and space for three to four trains.

Officials overseeing the dismantling work said that as of now, they had finished pulling down viaducts at the gate 1 bus stand but traffic disruption is likely in the coming weeks to facilitate the work on VIP Road and Jessore Road. “We have already sought permission from the cops for a traffic block. A huge crane is being used to pull down the viaduct that will block at least 27m of the thoroughfare. The cops have allowed us a night’s permission some time next week to work on VIP Road but there has been no official communication yet,” said an official overseeing the dismantling work.

Title: Kozhikode: Anti-smoking campaign in 271 schools
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

KOZHIKODE: District health department authorities have succeeded in ensuring the active participation of 271 high schools in the district for the Quit to care-anti-smoking campaign project.

The training programme will begin with two students and one school nodal officer from 271 high schools and these student volunteers will train another 20 students from each school in the coming days. Under the project, a total of 5,420 student volunteers of 271 high schools will adopt 27,100 persons who wish to quit smoking. The door-to-door survey to identify people who wish to quit smoking will begin as soon as the on-going training programme for student volunteers is completed in the district. The health department conducted the first phase of the training programme to the student volunteers the other day.

Title: Lt Gen Saini to take over as Army's new vice-chief
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

NEW DELHI: Lieutenant General S K Saini , the chief of the Pune-based Southern Command, will take over as the new Army vice-chief on January 25. The post was lying vacant since December 31 after General M M Naravane, the then vice-chief, took over the reins of the 1.3-million force from General Bipin Rawat, who in turn was appointed the chief of defence staff.

Lt-Gen C P Mohanty, in turn, is tipped to take over the Southern Command, while Lt-Gen Y K Joshi is likely to become the chief of the J&K-based Northern Command after Lt-Gen Ranbir Singh retires on January 31. Lt-Gen Saini, an alumnus of Sainik School Kapurthala , was commissioned into the 7 Jat Regiment in June 1981.

He has commanded a mountain brigade, a counter insurgency force in J&K and a corps in the western theatre facing Pakistan during his long career.

Title: Normalcy only after VC is sacked: JNU teachers
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

JNU professors during protest organized by JNU Teachers’ Association outside the School of International St... Read More NEW DELHI: In its general body meeting (GBM) on Friday, JNU Teachers ’ Association ( JNUTA ) reiterated that to restore normalcy on the campus, the vice-chancellor should be sacked. It also decided not to cooperate with the Jawaharlal Nehru University administration on resuming classes, saying the authorities should first try to end the impasse with students. JNUTA will seek a judicial inquiry into the January 5 violence on the campus as neither the “sham inquiry” of the VC-appointed committee nor Delhi Police’s investigation would bring to light the complete truth, the resolution claimed. “No teaching for the winter semester can commence before the academic activities of the monsoon semester are completed in a manner consistent with the statutory provisions and the maintenance of academic standards,” GBM stated. The teachers will engage with students but will not “accept the diktats of an administration that cannot even perform its job of ensuring a conducive environment for regular academic activities”, it pointed out. The teachers, who assembled in front of School of International Studies and raised slogans, alleged that as the administration didn’t not want a fair investigation, JNUTA demanded the sacking of the VC as a “necessary, though not sufficient, condition for teachers to feel secure. GBM... cautions MHRD that it will be held squarely responsible should the distinct possibility of any further untoward incidents becomes a reality because of the delay in relieving the VC”. The resolution rejected the registrar’s January 13 advisory alleging that it had “admonished teachers and threatened them”. After the “chilling experience of January”, there’s no doubt the VC and the administration “do indeed pose a serious threat” to the teachers, it stated. Demanding that the private security agency at JNU be held accountable for its failure on January 5 and be replaced, JNUTA sought “an urgent review of security arrangements, which must include the participation of teachers, students, staff and residents”. It also said the current security arrangements were causing inconveniences to every body.

Title: Bihar: Munger man kills wife, three kids & mother, attempts suicide
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A 45-year-old man killed his wife, three minor daughters and nonagenarian mother before attempting suicide by jumping from the third floor of the his house in Munger district early on Friday morning. The man, who was undergoing depression, survived and is in treatment but under police custody.

Police said around 4am Bharat Kesari strangled his wife Asha Devi (40), his daughters Shivrani (16), Shivran (14) and Sonam (12) while they were sleeping. He then strangled his 95-year-old mother Savitri Devi. All were fast asleep when they were killed. He then went to the third floor of the building and jumped off. He suffered serious injuries and was rushed to the local primary health centre from where he was referred to the Sadar hospital. He is said to be out of danger.

Haveli Kharagpur SDPO Polast Kumar said Bharat confessed to the crime and said he took the extreme step under duress. “Bharat was very upset after the agreement paper of his shop, Sonam Watch, went missing. The shop was allotted to him a few years ago by the district administration,” he said. He was worried of being evicted from his shop as its lease was to lapse soon, the SDPO said.

Title: Mercury dips after rain, hail in Dehradun, Mussoorie
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Rainfall and snow disrupted road connectivity and electricity supply in several parts of Uttarkashi

DEHRADUN/UTTARKASHI: Following spells of rainfall and hail , temperature levels dropped by a few notches below normal in Dehradun and surrounding areas on Friday. Dehradun city recorded a maximum temperature of 17.2 degrees Celsius, about two notches below normal, while the minimum temperature remained at 9 degrees Celsius.

Mussoorie residents also experienced chilly conditions with the minimum temperature settling at 6.5 degrees Celsius. Rainfall and overcast conditions were reported in and around the Queen of Hills.

Meanwhile, rainfall and snow disrupted road connectivity and electricity supply in several parts of Uttarkashi.

Snowfall in upper reaches of the district interrupted traffic movement at Gangotri and Yamunotri national highways ahead of Gangnani and Hanuman Chatti regions respectively, on Friday. Besides the two national highways, half-a-dozen link roads including Mukhba-Harsil, Kuwan-Kafnol, and Hanuman Chatti-Kharsali also got blocked due to a thick layer of snow on roads. Power supply in as many as 25 villages — including Pilang, Jaspur, Jhala, Kamad, Liwadi, Fitadi, and Rala — were also hit.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer, told TOI, “Road connectivity and power supply in most of the areas will get restored by Saturday morning. Personnel of all the concerned departments are working towards this end."

Title: 6 of 10 AMC hi-tech cleaning machines not functioning
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: Most of the hi-tech machines to lift garbage which were purchased by Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) 10 months ago are now lying defunct condition due to lack of proper maintenance. Ten of these machines were purchased by AMC at a cost of Rs 1 crore. They were to be deployed for high-standard cleanliness in the vicinity of the Taj Mahal and on MG road. The use of these machines would also have helped curb pollution caused by dust during cleaning work.

According to sources, AMC administration did not train the sanitation workers how to operate these machines. Today, at least six of the 10 machines are not functioning as the workers entrusted with them had little idea on how to operate or maintain the litter-pickers. As a result, the workers have gone back to manual cleaning.

The sources said these machines operated well for the first two months, keeping the areas spick and span. However, due to the lack of monitoring by senior officials, the mechanized cleaning plan soon fizzled out.

Mayor Naveen Jain said, “We have received complaints of mechanized cleaning work not taking place. A probe will be conducted. All the non-functional litter-picker machines will be repaired. The workers will be trained for proper operation and maintenance of the litter-picker machines.”

During the launch of the machines, civic body officials had said that the battery-mounted machine is equipped with a waste-collection tank of 240 litre. It has the capacity to make 9 square meter area litter free at a go.

Title: ‘Fire did not start in garbage dump’
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Panaji: Commissioner of the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) Sanjit Rodrigues refuted claims that the fire at the CCP ’s wet waste facility at Patto on Monday started from the dump , inside the shed.

The excavator in the pathway outside the wall of the shed caught fire first, he said, adding that it got fully burnt. The fire then proceeded to the dump inside the shed, he told corporators, who asked him whether the fire started from within the dump. “If the fire started inside, the JCB wouldn’t have been burnt,” he said.

He blamed the security guard from the government’s human resource corporation for not being present at the time of the fire and alerting authorities in time. He added that the gate was locked and the fire fighters had to cut open the gate before they could douse the fire that engulfed the dump.

If the guard was present on duty, he would have seen the smoke from the fire that started in the wee hours of Monday.

He asked the corporators to pass a resolution to request the government to hire private security from a professional security agency so that someone could be held accountable.

The major fire at the city’s garbage facility that handles 30 tonne of commercial waste a day took fire fighters 12 hours and 87,000 litres of water to put out. The loss to machinery and the shed was estimated at Rs 40 lakh while fire personnel helped save Rs 60 lakh.

Methane in the legacy dump at the site help the fire spread.

Title: Meerut Cantt Board cancels entry fee at three points amid protests by traders & transporters
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Meerut: After a month-long controversy around the new ‘entry fee’, introduced by Meerut Cantonment Board to raise funds for maintenance, the decision to collect toll at three points in the district was cancelled in a crucial Meerut Cantonment Board meeting on Wednesday.

The December 8 order that was cancelled by the board allowed a private contractor to collect an ‘entry fee’ from commercial vehicles. However, after protests, the board withdrew its order on December 12 and cancelled its contract with the contractor, at which point, the latter approached Allahabad high court and got a stay on the board’s directive on December 20.

Then from January 8, the contractor suddenly began collecting ‘entry fee’ without informing the cantonment authority, citing the HC stay order, at the three spots — Mawana road, Roorkee road and Jali Kothi — where the Meerut Cantonment Board had earlier set up barriers to collect entry fee to the restricted area. These were in addition to nine existing barriers. The fee ranged between Rs 25 and Rs 150, depending on the size of the vehicle.

Meerut Cantt CEO Prasad Chavan said, “It has been decided at the meeting that no entry fee will be charged from vehicles at these entry points. If the contractor continues to charge the fee, he will be stopped with the help of the district administration.”

Mamta Kansey, additional CEO, Meerut Cantt, said, “We did not give permission to the contractor to collect the fee, but the procedure was started without informing us.”

Title: Automated driving tests to become reality in Meerut by March?
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: On the lines of neighbouring Delhi, Meerut is also all set to get “smart tracks”, also called automated tracks, this year on which license seekers’ driving skills will be put on test. The new tracks to test the driving skills will be in the shape of 8 and cameras will record and feed every move to computers, which will then take a call if the driver is worthy of getting a license to drive on road, or not. The system is expected to weed out touts and curb corruption, the government believes so.

However, after 80% completion, the project seems to be stuck due to the alleged delay in release of the last installment of sanctioned budged by the state government.

According to the plan, the entire infrastructure to house the tracks and other systems was expected to be handed over to the authorities by March this year. However, in spite of the pending installment of Rs 54 lakh, authorities claim that they will be able to complete the work in time. The project was launched in 2015 with a target budget of Rs 4.46 crore.

Initially, plans were on to construct it in the RTO premises itself. However, later, a land in Industrial Training Institute (ITI) in Meerut was finalized.

“According to the details that we have in place, 80% of the driving track has been completed and the remaining will be completed once the pending Rs 54 lakh is released by the state government. I have already sent a demand letter to the higher ups and waiting for the release of the money,” said Vijay Kumar, Meerut regional transport officer.

As of now, the driving skills of license seekers are tested first through a road safety norms test on computers and then by checking their driving skills on a limited patch of land in the RTO office and around it. Questions are often raised on the transparency of these tests and allegations are made about bribes being taken to get a green signal in these tests.

Once the computerized driving track, in the shape of the number 8, is in the place, human intervention will come down.

SK Singh, executive engineer of UP Rajya Nirmaan Sehkaari Sangh, said, “The construction work started in August 2018. The proposal was given to us in 2018 but it got delayed because initially we were asked to replicate the driving track in Kanpur. Later, we were told to take a nod from The Central Institute of Road Transport, Pune, which suggested certain amendments and then the work picked up pace in August 2018.”

“We have already sent a request for the pending Rs 54 lakh installment, and it is supposed to arrive in the next two weeks. After which we will be able to hand over the track as well as the building constructed for the theoretical lessons before the track by March 2020. Only automation work will remain, which has to be completed by the RTO authorities,” said Singh.

Title: Delhi university professor slams AMU VC, says he should step down
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: Delhi University professor Apoorvanand Jha on Friday slammed vice chancellors of Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ), JNU and Jamia Millia Islamia for what he said their failure to protect the students from outside assault and suggested they should tender their resignations.

“The VCs of all three universities including AMU should accept that they could not protect their students and should quit from their posts,” said professor Jha while addressing teachers in AMU on Friday. Jha alleged that it was a complete failure of the VCs across all universities where violence took place. “AMU VC Tariq Mansoor, who allowed police inside the campus on December 15, should also accept his failure,” he said.

“How can you make an eye contact with students after this incident? You are custodian of the university and students are your responsibility,” he said.

Jha asked, “I wonder how the VC is so relaxed and calm after such barbaric incident, in which one of his students lost hand.”

Referring to recent Amendment to Citizenship Law, Jha said, “We did not raise our voice at the time of abrogation of Article 370 in the Kashmir Valley and that is why we are facing this”.

“The country is at a very dangerous crossroads and only youths can make others understand about it,” he said.

Professor Jha also spoke about the importance of the role of public universities, which he said “have taken the role of the guardians of the Constitution.” Senior journalist Qurban Ali, who was also present there, spoke at length about the inclusive nature of the country and about the struggle for Independence. Ali appealed to the government to rollback laws like CAA, which, for the first time, have created divisions.

Title: Making space for generation next: 10 young leaders to take poll plunge
Content:
Shivani Chopra

Akanksha Ola

NEW DELHI: The first list of 54 candidates announced by Congress on Saturday has about 10 young leaders making their debut into the electoral politics in the Delhi assembly polls.While some have been active in Youth Congress , a few have been working closely with their illustrious fathers, who have won several elections and held important organisational positions in the party and are all slowly making a way for the second generation to take forward the family mantle.Among prominent second-generation leaders are Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra’s daughter, Shivani (Kalkaji), former speaker Yoganand Shastri’s daughter, Priyanka (RK Puram), and former Model Town MLA Kunwar Karan Singh’s daughter, Akanksha Ola (Model Town). Former Mustafabad MLA Hasan Ahmed’s son, Ali Mehndi, and Nangloi Jat MLA Birender Singh’s son, Mandeep, are also in the fray from the seats their fathers represented in Delhi assembly.The party has also relied on several Youth Congress leaders, including Radhika Khera, former DUSU president Neetu Verma (Malviya Nagar), Siddharth Kundu (Narela), Gaurav Dhanak (Karol Bagh) and Sandeep Tanwar (Delhi Cantonment).Akanksha Ola, who is currently secretary, All India Mahila Congress, said, the party has taken a wise decision by promoting youth and women. “To bring a change in the society, it is important to empower women,” said Ola (41), who has been politically active with her father for almost 20 years now.Priyanka Singh, vice-president, Delhi Mahila Congress, has been politically active since 2008. Ironically, she has been nominated for her first election on a day her father quit the party. “My father always told me to find my own feet in politics and get ticket with my hard work not because I am her daughter,” Singh said.Shivani, however, is relatively new to politics. Bar-at-Law from London, she recently joined her father in the political work. “I am really excited. My aim is to carry forward Congress’ tradition of progress and continue the chain of development started by Sheila Dikshit and broken by the AAP government,” Shivani said.Radhika Khera has been active in politics for a long time and currently is national secretary and social media head of Indian Youth Congress. She also handled Delhi Congress’ social media in the 2015 assembly polls. She has been fielded from Janakpuri.

Title: Protesting students boycott AMU proctor’s visit to dharna site
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: A group of students protesting against CAA and NRC at Bab-e-Syed gate of Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) boycotted the proctor’s visit to the dharna site on Friday. Some agitated ex-students also misbehaved with the proctor but they were stopped by the student leaders present there.

Two former students’ union office-bearers, Nadeem Ansari and Hamza Sufyan, against whom the district police have already initiated the process of invoking the UP Control of Goondas Act, 1970, allegedly misbehaved with the proctor and asked him to go back. They questioned his whereabouts when students were being allegedly beaten up by the police on December 15.

Varsity spokesperson Shafey Kidwai later said that this kind of act is not acceptable. “Since they are not students of AMU, we will report the incident to the police,” said Kidwai. He said Sufyan had been rusticated by the university administration for five years for creating ruckus at the vice-chancellor’s office and for allegedly misbehaving with the varsity employees in July 2019. Ansari is also not the student of AMU at present, he said.

Students’ leader Faizul Hassan told TOI that he tried to stop Ansari and Sufyan, who created ruckus at the protest site. He said, “We will not tolerate this nuisance and will stand against them if they repeat this in future. We are here to protest against CAA peacefully not for creating ruckus.”

He added that their demand for the resignation by VC Tariq Mansoor and Registrar Abdul Hamid stands, as “they were responsible for police action on the campus”. “Also, the protest against contentious CAA/NRC/NPR will continue till the government withdraws the law,” he added.

Following the incident, Proctor Afifullah Khan re-issued a notification, saying that as per the directions of the Allahabad high court, the Duck Pond in the university has been earmarked as the site for students to congregate freely in peaceful manner to protest.

Title: RSS role in Ram temple ended after SC verdict, says Bhagwat
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat on Thursday said that the Sangh’s role in creating public opinion and awareness about the importance of construction of the Ram temple has ended after the Supreme Court’s judgement in the matter. The Sangh supremo also said that shrines of Kashi and Mathura were not its agenda.

Answering queries from RSS volunteers during a question-answer session on the first day of his four-day visit to Moradabad, he said that it is now up to the government and the trust to start the temple’s construction. He further said that Vishwa Hindu Parishad’s role, however, will continue till the construction of the temple is started.

According to sources, Bhagwat, who interacted with province (prant) and area (chhetra) office-bearers of Braj, Meerut and Uttrakhand regions, said that Sangh’s interest was limited only to the Ram temple and they did not have the reclamation of disputed religious sites at Mathura and Kashi on its agenda. Around 90 volunteers were present in the session.

Replying to the queries of volunteers over the ongoing protests and nationwide unrest over Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), Bhagwat reiterated the Sangh’s support to Modi government on the issue, saying that the organisation would not step back on the issue as it is beneficial for people. He also exhorted the volunteers to sensitize people on the Citizenship Act.

Sources told TOI that Sangh volunteers will participate in a rally which is being organised by the BJP in Agra on January 23 to spread awareness about CAA. They said that around 1.5 lakh people will be gathered at Kothi Meena Bazar for the rally to spread the message that CAA was beneficial for everyone.

Talking to TOI, a senior RSS functionary said that Bhagwat emphasised on expansion of the organisation to the basti and mandal level to reach out to every section of the society. He said that Bhagwat wanted to add more good people in the organsation.

Title: Traders on strike burn effigy of AMC over parking fee row
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: Traders of Sanjay Place market here who have been on an indefinite strike for the last three days burnt an effigy of Agra Municipal Corporation ( AMC ) administration on Friday. Traders are protesting against the civic body for charging parking fee at 44 places in the market. They claimed that it violates norms as they had already paid a fee for parking at the time of purchasing the property.

The traders have claimed that the parking fee is illegal. They have been using the public address system to urge vehicle owners not to pay for parking.

On his part, the parking contractors have said they have been authorized by the AMC administration to charge parking fee.

The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) is sub judice. The traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final orders in the matter.

Hiren Agarwal, secretary of the Sanjay Place market association, said, “We have already paid for the parking space. It is clearly written on the registry of the properties available with the property owners. The AMC administration is trying to exploit traders by illegally charging the parking fee. We are not going to tolerate this. The parking contractors will not be allowed to operate in Sanjay Place.”

Sanjay Place market was developed by the Agra Development Authority (ADA). In 2005, the market was handed over to the municipal corporation.

Traders claim that the municipal corporation was required to collect property tax, conduct maintenance work and look after street lighting and sewer system. There was no mention of collecting parking fee in the document handed over to them.

Association's treasurer Vinay Mittal said, “We have received support of over a dozen organizations in our protest against the parking mafia. In violation of the norms, the AMC administration has allowed people associated with BJP to charge the parking fee. AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected from the market. This is the reason no one from the ruling party or any AMC official has come to discuss the issue. In past, we have raised the entire matter with Mayor Naveen Jain, but they didn’t provide any solution.”

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “Charging fee for parking on public place is right of the civic body. The fee collected will be used for development works and improving maintenance of sanitation and hygiene. The matter of parking in Sanjay Place is sub judice and we will go by the court orders. The claims made by the market association are misleading.”

Title: UPPCL junior engineer shot dead in Mathura
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Agra: A junior engineer of the Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) was shot dead by unidentified assailants while returning home from work in Mathura’s Pani village on Thursday night.

The deceased was identified as Pradeep Kumar (36) from Agra, who was posted in Mathura.

On Friday, his UPPCL colleagues boycotted work and staged a protest seeking justice for Kumar. They also demanded a compensation of Rs 1 crore to the relatives of the victim.

Mathura SSP Shalabh Mathur said, “The body has been sent for postmortem. We are looking into all angles. An inquiry is on.”

District magistrate Sarvagya Ram Misra said that he has received a memorandum from the UPPCL employees. “We will try to fulfil the demands raised by them,” he added.

Title: Pay-parking in Panaji may be retendered
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

CCP has awarded the contract on nine road stretches to Sohan Juwarker

PANAJI: The Corporation of the City of Panaji ( CCP ) may retender the pay-parking contract after the highest bidder, who quoted Rs 1.62 crore for three years, asked the corporation for a month’s time to pay the 60% bank guarantee for three years.

Alternatively, the bidder asked the corporation whether instead of paying 60% bank guarantee for the three years upfront, which amounts to Rs 97 lakh, it could pay the 60% bank guarantee for the first year only.

CCP mayor Uday Madkaikar said if one month’s time is granted, the code of conduct for the zilla panchayat elections would further delay the project till April. He said that when he sought legal opinion on whether the bank guarantee could be accepted only for one year, he was told that the tender document couldn’t be changed.

“We will write to the bidder saying both these options are not possible and see what he says. If he doesn’t agree we will have to retender it,” he told TOI.

CCP has awarded the contract on nine road stretches in the state capital to Sohan Juwarker for Rs 1.6 crore.

CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues said the bank guarantee was fixed high at 60% because the CCP burnt its hands with the last pay-parking contract.

“We wanted a professional and sound party who has the money and whose cheques will not bounce. This was explained to the council and the bidder was aware of this,” he said.

“The bidder knew very clearly how much security to keep. Now that the bid has been accepted we cannot change the terms. We cannot talk to the second highest bidder either according to the central vigilance commission,” Rodrigues told corporators.

The agreement between the contractor and CCP cannot be signed until the 60% bank guarantee and 10% security amount are deposited.

Title: Udupi soaks in paryaya spirit
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Udupi: The paryaya will be a colourful affair with 101 cultural troupes leading Eeshapriya Teertha ’s procession to Car Street at 2am on Saturday.

Early on Saturday morning, after taking a bath at DandaTeertha, Eeshapriya Teertha will be brought to Krishna temple with the Paryaya procession which will reach the mutt at 4.30 am. Once he reaches the temple, the important Paryaya Peetharohana function begins, where the outgoing Paryaya seer (Vidyadheesha Teertha) hands over the Akshaya Patre and the Sattuga (vessel and ladle dating back to the times of Sri Madhwacharya) and the keys to the sanctum sanctorum to the incoming paryaya seer. Then the traditional darbar happens inside the Badagumalige with Ashta Mutt seers.

After the Badagumaalige meeting, the new seer performs his first ‘Krishna Puja or Maha Puja’ at 9.30am. Then at 10.30 am, Annasantharpane for the public starts. The public Paryaya Durbar function will begin at the Rajangana Hall at 2.30 pm.

The Paryayotsava of Admar Mutt officially begins at 7 pm on Friday with felicitation ceremony ‘Sarvajanika Sanmana’ for the existing Paryaya seer Vidyadheesha Teertha Swami of Palimaru Mutt. There will be Rathothsava at Car Street at 8 pm, then the paryaya procession will start at 2 am on Saturday from Jodukkatte.

As per the instructions of Eeshapriya Teertha, the committee has given permission for tableaux which will spread positive messages for society. The tableaux will also lay emphasis on highlighting the culture of Tulunadu and Karnataka.

There are five tableaux from Udupi CMC, agriculture department, zilla panchayat and PWD. There will be 15 cultural presentations from the department of Kannada and culture as per the instructions from minister C T Ravi.

There are stages set for the grand biennial paryaya festival at different junctions to organise entertainment events. They are at Kinnimulki, Geethanjali textiles, Poorna Prajna College, Ajjarkadu, Town Hall, Board high school, Christian high school, service bus stand and old taluk office. The city is illuminated with miniature lights for the occasion. The speciality of this year’s Paryaya is that the entire city is decorated with traditional lanterns.

Title: Hyderabad: Rohith Vemula’s mother to launch anti-CAA yatra
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Radhika Vemula at Rohith Vemula’s memorial in University of Hyderabad, on Friday

HYDERABAD: On the fourth death anniversary of Rohith Vemula , his mother Radhika Vemula appealed to the Hyderabadis to take to the streets to protest the ‘unconstitutional policies’ of the central government. “I couldn’t save my son, but I want to save my nation,” she said on Friday.

On January 17, 2016, Rohith Vemula, a Dalit scholar, had committed suicide allegedly after facing caste-discrimination in the University of Hyderabad. The 26-year-old PhD student was found hanging in his hostel room.

Recalling what Rohith mentioned in his last letter, she said people are reduced to votes. “I am sad and enraged about what is happening with the students of Jawaharlal Nehru University and Jamia Millia Islamia. Even after four years of Rohith’s institutional murder, the situation in the country is same and students are not safe. They are being distinguished based on their caste and religion,” she added.

“I, along with Abeda Salim Tadvi and Fatima Nafees, would launch ‘Mothers for the Nation Yatra’ – a nationwide anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) tour, to mobilise support for united India and defend basic principles of Ambedkar’s Constitution,” Radhika Vemula said.

Fatima Nafees is mother of Najeeb Ahmed, a 27-year-old student of biotechnology at JNU, who went missing in October 2016, allegedly after a scuffle with ABVP members.

Abeda Salim Tadvi is mother of Payal Tadvi, a medical student from National Medical College and BYL Nair Hospital in Mumbai, who killed herself in May 2019, allegedly due to caste-discrimination.

Radhika also visited Rohith Vemula’s memorial in UoH and garlanded the statue. She said financial difficulties have kept her away from participating in any protest. She further said that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah should to prove their identity first by showing documents of their forefathers, before questioning others.

Speaking at the event ‘We The People of India’, Swaraj Abhiyan chief Yogendra Yadav said the fight against CAA, National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) have become a movement across the nation. Terming the movement as ‘Bharat Jodo Andolan’ like ‘Bharat Chhodo Andolan’ (Quit India Movement), he said the Centre will continue to divide and rule, but we will continue to unite and fight.

“We need to reclaim our Constitution. The freedom movement was to form a nation where people of all religions get equal rights,” Yadav said, adding that democracy, diversity and development have been put at stake by the government.

Stressing on the need to keep the protests non-violent, Yadav said, “Violence will lynch the movement and the only way we can achieve our aim is by remaining aggressively non-violent.”

Title: Cities changing in face of displacement, says architect who works with refugees
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

London architect Joana Dabaj of Syrian-Lebanese descent has rebuilt spaces near refugee settlements

MUMB AI: Despite her deliberately modest clothing, well-groomed Londoner Joana Dabaj—an architect of Lebanese-Syrian descent—often jutted out as she worked amidst Syrian refugee settlements of Lebanon in 2016. Intrigued by a Lebanese-speaking woman with “foreign features” leading a team of multi-cultural volunteers who were rebuilding a school nearby, several refugees would approach her with questions ranging from “Can I borrow that tool?” to “Will you marry me?”

So, one fine day, when Dabaj saw a Syrian man pull up his van next to her, she assumed her foreignness had given yet another passerby the invitation to “waste my time” with small talk. But he surprised her. “Jumana,” he said, using the local corruption of her name. “I have three daughters... Whenever I drive them to school, I pass this site and ask them to look at you and be like you.”

Today, as Dabaj recounts this memory to TOI, her grey eyes widen like those of the cats she likes to rescue everywhere she goes. “That was one of my favourite moments,” says Dabaj, speaking both as co-founder of Catalytic Action, a UK-based non-profit design studio that works to empower vulnerable communities in Middle East, and as a woman architect who was in Mumbai last week for a conference titled ‘ Women In Design 2020 ’.

Held at Nehru Centre, the conference saw Dabaj taking the audience through the nuances of how her non-profit had rebuilt spaces, including schools and playgrounds, near refugee settlements by enlisting Lebanese and Syrian volunteers in the construction process, using local material like sheep wool to insulate the structures and even encouraging inputs from children before designing.

For instance, while working along with other NGOs on Jarahieh School—a dark, windowless, tented structure infested with rats and stuffy from the noise of a nearby wood burner till 2015—Dabaj and her artist friend asked schoolkids to tell them what they wanted the school to look like through activities such as performances and drawings. “They came up with everything from where they wanted the bathroom to be to where the doorkeeper must sleep,” says Dabaj, who too soon featured in their sketches as a figure that napped, clicked pictures and “bossed people around”.

Bossing people around on this project also meant overseeing the arrival of giant shipments, helping empty the school’s septic tank and building a sturdy enough rapport with local municipality to ensure they would link the bathroom to the sewage line—a privilege refugees were exempt from.

Driven by the belief that “working on infrastructure for vulnerable communities does not mean compromising on the quality of construction”, Dabaj and her Italian business partner Riccardo Luca Conti also enlisted the help of local women in insulating the walls of the school with locally available sheep wool. “Good architecture means having a good local knowhow,” says Dabaj, who also used secondhand green iron sheets bought from a local farmer as rain screens for the project. “Many locals came up to tell us that iron sheets was a smart idea,” says Dabaj, who found herself resolving locals’ technical queries about engineering tools in Lebanese.

For weeks, they slaved away at the school that soon housed brightly lit classrooms and even doubled up as a safe enclosed space for women to hold yoga classes, among other things.

Today, her non-profit has not only built customised playground equipment like swings and rollers using local material but is also undertaking research on how to make cities more child-friendly. “We have to think of how cities and towns are changing in the face of displacement due to climate change and how to ensure dignified living conditions for not only the poor living on the margins but also the urban poor,” says Dabaj, stressing the need for NGOs and trusts to consider empowering communities through urban design by enlisting experts. “Architecture,” she says, echoing late Italian architect GiancarloDe Carlo’s sentiment, “is too important to be left to architects alone.”

Title: Manipur: Man gets life term for raping minor
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

Title: Bihar: 3 robberies in one day, petrol pumps threaten agitation
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Unidentified armed criminals struck again on Friday and looted over Rs 20 lakh in three incidents in Samastipur, Patna and Vaishali districts. Angry over frequent incidents of cash loot from petrol pumps, the petroleum dealers’ association gave an ultimatum of 72 hours to Vaishali police to arrest the culprits, failing which they will launch an agitation.

Reports reaching the state police headquarters said four criminals entered the office of a private finance company near Saidpur Mela Gate under the Chak Mehasi police station in Samastipur district around 10am and looted cash amounting to Rs 17 lakh after holding the employees captive at gunpoint. The robbers had come as customers.

The company’s credit manager, Md Sadaquat Ansari, told the police that he was sitting with an employee, Subhash Kumar, when the robbers carried out the operation. The office gate was shut as the accounts were being checked. The robbers entered the office in the guise of customers wanting to deposit money. As soon as the gate was opened, they held the employees captive. “I had no option but to hand over the keys of the locker. They collected Rs 17,35,560 and escaped on their motorbikes, which were parked outside. I raised an alarm but they had escaped with two bags full of cash. They also took away my mobile phone. By then the local people had arrived.” DSP Pritish Kumar, who rushed to the spot, said the CCTVs were not working as they had developed some fault.

In another incident, unidentified armed motorbike-borne criminals looted Rs 2.37 lakh from an employee of a cold storage when he was about to enter a bank near Anisabad Mor under the Gardanibagh police station area here.

In Vaishali, unidentified criminals looted Rs70,000 from an employee of a cooking gas agency near ROB under Hajipur sadar police station. Two criminals, who had covered their faces with cloths, reached the spot and snatched the bag containing money when the employee was engaged in collecting cash from vendors. Later, Hajipur additional SP Raghav Dayal visited the spot and inquired about the daylight cash loot from the employee of the agency, owned by a senior BJP leader of Muzaffarpur.

Title: Market agreements: CCP mayor to call for meet in Feb
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Panaji: Receiving flak from corporators for not signing agreements with illegal occupants in the Panaji municipal market, commissioner of the Corporation of the City of Panaji Sanjit Rodrigues blamed corporators for not calling a single meeting of the market committee.

If the market’s association doesn’t agree on signing agreements, the mayor should go to court to get them evicted, he said, adding that “all the budget which is coming from citizens taxes is going into private pockets”.

He blamed corporators for entertaining 30 objections from the market association. “Our staff is confused whether to entertain this or not. Some of them want to sign agreements, but we don’t have an agreement and we don’t have a rate,” he stated.

When all arrangements were made, one day before signing the agreement, the market association said they didn’t want to sign a leave and licence agreement, but a leave agreement. “The leave and licence agreement was decided on with their consultation, so where’s the question to change it. This will mean another two years. We should stick to one agreement, which is done in consultation with them,” he told the corporators at the meeting.

Corporator Rahul Lotlikar said the association was coming up with unreasonable demands and added that the corporation shouldn’t bend backwards. Corporator Rupesh Harlarnkar said the market is a mess and a concrete decision is required to be taken in the matter. Corporators agreed that all registration charges should be borne by the occupants of the market.

Following an uproar from corporators, mayor Uday Madkaikar agreed to call for meeting in the first week of next month to finalise the agreements to be signed with the illegal tenants at the market.

With no agreements signed, the corporation has not received a single rupee towards rent from the illegal occupants in its municipal market. It, however, collects sopo daily from the small vegetable, fruit and flower vendors in the market.

Title: Sukhna: UT says 100m ESZ proposal of Punjab a threat
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

The UT administration has termed as a threat Punjab’s 2013 proposal to declare only 100-metre of state’s area... Read More

CHANDIGARH: The UT administration has termed as a threat Punjab’s 2013 proposal to declare only 100-metre of state’s area around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as an eco-sensitive zone (ESZ). Punjab chief minister Capt Amarinder Singh had recently backed the state government’s proposal.

UT chief conservator of forests Debendra Dalai, in a letter to the director general of forests and special secretary, ministry of environment, forest and climate change, has opposed the Punjab government’s plan.

The UT administration has already notified 2 to 2.75km radius around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as an ESZ. The Union environment ministry had also issued a final notification on ESZ around the sanctuary for Chandigarh, but Punjab and Haryana have so far not declared these zones in their jurisdictions.

UT is pushing for Punjab and Haryana to leave a matching area from the lake boundary as restricted development zone. UT, in a letter written on January 14, stated, “The ESZ for the area falling in Chandigarh around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary has already been notified by the ministry on January 18, 2017, wherein ESZ has been kept 2 to 2.75 km and regulating/prohibiting various activities therein. However, the proposal of Punjab is not in line with the proposal of UT Chandigarh… Further, it is to reiterate that similar proposal of the Punjab government, which was sent to the government of India in 2015, was not accepted by the Centre. In 2018, the government of India once again turned down the proposal of Punjab government proposing only 100m width as ESZ from Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary. In case only 100m is left as ESZ, it will have serious adverse impact on Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as well as Sukhna Lake (sic).”

The UT has requested the ministry not to accept Punjab’s proposal in the interest of wildlife conservation in the sanctuary as well as for Sukhna Lake, which is being declared as a wetland, draft notification for which has already been issued by the administration.

Earlier on December 27 last, the Punjab CM wrote to the Union minister of environment, forest and climate change Prakash Javadekar, “In the light of recommendations made by the Punjab government, the ministry has already notified ESZ of 100m width around all the wildlife sanctuaries of Punjab. However, the proposal of Punjab government in respect of declaring 100m ESZ around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary has not been agreed upon by the ministry on the basis that Chandigarh had proposed ESZ of 2 to 2.75km, and therefore the ministry advised Punjab to explore the possibility of declaring 1km ESZ instead of the proposed ESZ of 100m. Thereafter, the Punjab government reconsidered its decision of declaring 100m ESZ and it was found that the decision taken by the Punjab government on August 8, 2013, was in line with the recommendation of the central-empowered committee of the Supreme Court.”

How 1km proposal will affect Punjab

If the Union ministry agrees to Punjab’s proposal of 100m ESZ, it will be a relief for residents of Kansal and Nayagaon villages in the state. For, the 1km suggestion given by the ministry, which is being backed by the UT administration as well, will affect the people residing in these areas. A senior Punjab government official said almost the entire area of Kansal and many parts of Nayagaon would come under 1km radius and there would be restrictions on construction activity in the buffer zone. These villages are thickly populated and some areas of lal dora also come within the 1km buffer zone.

The case diary

January 14: UT writes to ministry, opposing Punjab’s proposal

December 27, 2019: The Punjab CM writes to the Union minister of environment, forest and climate change backing the state’s 100m proposal

December 4, 2019: Punjab additional chief secretary for forests and wildlife preservation Roshan Sankaria writes to environment ministry secretary C K Mishra to declare 100m ESZ for areas falling in the state

May 8, 2019: In a letter to the Centre, Punjab once again backs its decision taken in August 8, 2013, meeting

July 16, 2018: Centre requests Punjab to reconsider its proposal and send a revised one after exploring the possibilities of declaring an ESZ of up to 1km

January 18, 2017: The Union ministry issues ESZ notification for Chandigarh declaring 2 to 2.75 kilometre radius from Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary as ESZ

September 17, 2015: Ministry issues draft notification only for Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary area under UT and not for those under Punjab and Haryana

July 25, 2014: UT opposes Punjab’s proposal. In a letter to the Union government, it states that Punjab’s limit of 100m is small, more so when its areas adjoining Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary are being developed as high-density nagar panchayats and Nayagaon municipality

August 8, 2013: Punjab’s proposal of declaring a 100m ESZ around Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary approved by the state council of ministers in a meeting

Title: UPCL engineer arrested for taking Rs 75,000 bribe
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: The sleuths of vigilance department on Friday arrested a junior engineer of Uttarakhand Power Corporation Limited ( UPCL ) while accepting a bribe of Rs 75,000 from a resident of Dehradun .

The accused, identified as Munish Kumar, who was posted at UPCL sub-station in Selaqui area of Dehradun, had allegedly demanded bribe of Rs 80000 from a local resident for permanent power connection and installing electricity poll.

After making repeated pleas, the errant UPCL engineer agreed to reduce the bribe amount to Rs 75,000 and told him that work will start once the money is paid.

Instead of paying the bribe, the complainant approached the vigilance department and filed a complaint. After examining the complaint, a trap team was formed and Kumar was arrested red-handed while accepting Rs 75,000 bribe from the complainant. He has been booked under section 7(a) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

Title: CT Ravi’s ‘beef’ with Kerala ad backfires
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

CT Ravi

BENGALURU: The government slammed Kerala ’s tourism department for putting out a tweet on Sankranti Day, promoting ‘beef ularthiyathu’, a specialty in that state, but the move backfired spectacularly with Karnataka ’s tourism minister being heavily trolled.

After Kerala put out its advertisement, state tourism minister CT Ravi , seizing the opportunity, took a dig at the Left government in Kerala, saying, “Welcome to Karnataka”. He followed that up with another tweet listing delicious “vegetarian” dishes of coastal Karnataka — a coastline which runs to Kerala.

“Welcome to Karnataka to bring out the Vegetarian in you. Enjoy the flavors of Tulu Nadu – Pathrode, Kotte Kadubu, Halasina Hannina Gatti, Avalakki Upkari, Badanekayi Mosaru Gojju and a whole lot of authentic food to hit Your tastebuds,” Ravi’s tweet read.

Ravi’s tweet sparked a debate between those for and against eating beef, including legislators like Sowmya Reddy (Congress) and Shobha Karandlaje (BJP). Some pointed out that Karnataka is 80% non-vegetarian and an appropriate response to beef curry would have been “pandi curry” (wild pig curry) — a Kodagu specialty.

Realising his tweets were getting more negative than positive traction, Ravi quickly amended his stand and on Friday tweeted: “Nati Koli Saaru Mudde. Aw! Delightful Delicacy of Old Mysuru region. Farm bred Chicken traditionally cooked to perfection and served with the soft Ragi Mudde. You will ask for more !!!”

Title: Depositors of Mapusa bank approach cops
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Panaji: Spelling further trouble for Mapusa Urban Cooperative Bank (MUCB), depositors have filed a complaint at Panaji police station and with the Economic Offences Cell seeking a through investigation into the financial mismanagement of the bank.

Depositors have also written to Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman and the Reserve Bank of India with a request to appoint administrators to manage the bank.

“The depositors of the bank are mostly senior citizens and we have requested the finance minister to intercede and not entertain any application from Mapusa Urban Cooperative Bank for cancellation of the banking licence or for deregistering from the Central Registrar of Co-operative Societies until the grievances concerning the deposits of the customers are settled in full,” a depositor Joseph Carneiro said.

On July 24, 2015, RBI had imposed financial restrictions on MUCB, preventing the multi-state cooperative bank from lending, after the latter’s cash reserve ratio turned negative. The RBI sanctions were extended till February 18. If the bank does not find any solution, it is likely to face liquidation.

RBI has allowed each depositor of the cooperative bank to withdraw up to Rs 50,000 from their account, but has said that if there are any unpaid loans, the money being withdrawn must be used to repay the loans.

On January 14, several depositors met to chalk out how their funds, which are locked with the bank due to the RBI’s sanctions, could be protected and removed. With no clear steps being taken to revive the bank, the depositors decided to file a complaint. The depositors also met RBI officials in Goa and demanded that action should be taken against the bank’s management.

“Section 36AA of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949, provides that RBI may supersede the board of directors of the banking company,” another depositor Prabhakar Salgaocar said.

The depositors have accused all the board of directors and senior management of mismanagement, fraud, manipulation and favouritism while sanctioning loans.

“Several of these above managerial personalities are blood relations of the founder member of the bank Ramakant Khalap,” Carneiro said.

MUCB needs around Rs 50 crore as share capital infusion in order to improve its Capital to Risk (Weighted) Assets Ratio (CRAR) and be free of RBI’s sanctions.

Title: Kolkata: Face-recognition technology helps cops solve mystery of lost bangle
Content:
CCTV cameras outside a departmental store in the mall.

TimesView CCTVs now cover almost every corner of the city and have helped cops solve crime on several occasions. They are also prone to misuse by individuals, especially inside private property. The Mani Square incident falls somewhere in between; CCTVs at a public space have helped solve what was very close to a crime being committed without criminal charges having to be pressed finally. The city’s CCTV cover should be increased judiciously, taking into account all the concerns and fears that come with such technology.

KOLKATA: A tale of moral quandary could have ended in being registered as a criminal case had it not been for a face-recognition software.The mystery of a lost diamond-studded gold bangle worth Rs 2.5 lakh, which fell off the hand of a 32-year-old Bowbazar homemaker at a popular mall last Sunday and then became the “object of desire” of two other visitors, was solved with the new software helping connect disjointed CCTV images and zero in on the two individuals. CCTV images and the software showed that the first visitor—a senior railway employee who was with her mother—did pick up the bangle but threw it away. The second visitor, a private bank employee, later picked up the bangle, apparently tried to find a guard to deposit it to him but decided against it and walked out with it. Phoolbagan police station cops checked 12 CCTV cameras at the mall, six of them inside the main mall, two of them inside a departmental store, two at an apparel store and two others faced towards the road.The entire technology-driven investigation lasted 48 hours. Kolkata Police said the sleuths used two recently acquired tools— one, a GIS-based mapping software that showed the exact locations of all CCTV cameras, including the private ones, and two, a software that helped match faces. “We went through 63 frames and found the bangle dropped off near the departmental store. The railway employee was seen bending down close to the store and picking up something. She is then seen being warned by her mother. She threw the bangle to the left corner, close to the escalator. We obtained her number from the departmental store, where she had gone, and recorded her statement,” an officer said.Police said they also chanced upon a CCTV frame, showing a man bending near the departmental store. “We began matching his clothes with that of people on the ground floor but traced him to the floor above. He was seen entering the apparel store, from where we got his number. We contacted the bank employee and got the bangle back,” said an officer.“CCTVs can work wonders. Kolkata Police have begun working on the ambitious project to integrate as many CCTV cameras as possible — both government and private — across the city. The idea is to ensure that footage is analysed in depth and every CCTV is mapped,” said an officer from the Watch section at Lalbazar. While the project has been successful in Posta, Park Street, Shakespeare Sarani and Bhowanipore, cops are looking to increase the cover in Behala, Jadavpur, Survey Park, Haridevpur and Regent Park.

Title: Traditional decor for seer’s palanquin
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Udupi: All the Ashta Mutt seers participate in the paryaya procession which happens once in two years. Each Astha Mutt seer will have the right to choose their palanquin and its decoration. On the occasion of Admar seer Eeshapriya Teertha’s paryaya procession on Saturday, Vishwaprasanna Teertha of Pejawar mutt will have his palanquin decorated in the traditional manner (Tulunadu style) with coconut fronds , bamboo sticks and banana stems.

Usually decorated with a silk cloth

The seer wanted to give a touch of traditional artistry. Usually, the palanquin where the swamiji sits during the procession is decorated with a silk cloth. Sadhu Panera, 64, and his colleagues Narayana Paranara, Girish Parana, Prajwal Parana and Dinesh Paranawas from Alevoor, Manchikere, were given the responsibility to prepare the traditional palanquin for the Pejawar Mutt seer.

They are experts in making the ‘Siri Singara’ and other accessories used by the artistes of Daiva dance. However, decorating a palanquin is a new experience for them.

Siri toppis an attraction

Vishwaprasannn Teertha said, “These festivities allow artists to develop their art and enhance culture and tradition. An attraction for the paryaya procession will be the ‘siri toppi’ hat made with coconut leaves by a Jharkhand youth. The swamiji was impressed with a young man who made the hat with coconut leaves, while he was in Bengaluru.

“He bought 25 such hats from him, which will be used during the procession on Saturday.”

Title: Goa: Nu-Shi Nalini auctioned for Rs 13.5 crore to Global Tankers FZE
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Insurance and Surveyors and Loss Assessors Private Ltd had valued the chemical tanker at `13.3 crore, includin... Read More

PANAJI: The stricken chemical tanker Nu-Shi Nalini , which was grounded near Raj Bhavan, has been sold through an auction monitored by the high court of Bombay to Global Tankers FZE for Rs 13.5 crore, officials said.

The ship continues to remain anchored at Mormugao Port Trust till Global Tankers FZE pays the entire amount for the ship, the deputy sheriff of the Bombay high court said. MPT is also in the process to calculating the expenditure incurred till date, which will be submitted to the court for recovery from the sale amount.

Insurance and Surveyors and Loss Assessors Private Ltd, appointed by the court, had valued the chemical tanker at Rs 13.3 crore, which included cost of towage of the vessel . The firm also felt that the ship has to be scrapped.

Global Tankers has paid Rs 2 crore and has to pay the balance Rs 11.5 crore by January 24.

“It is made clear that if the balance amount is not remitted by January 24, and no extension will be given to pay the balance amount, Rs 2 crore will stand forfeited and this court will also recover any amount that may be deficit, if the vessel has to be sold again, from Global Tankers FZE. Apart from that, contempt proceedings will be initiated against Global Tankers FZE and its directors,” Justice K R Shriram said in an order pertaining to the commercial admiralty suit between MPT, Samson Maritime Ltd and the owners of Nu Shi Nalini.

The chemical tanker ran aground on the rocks near Dona Paula with about 2,000 tonne naphtha , 50 tonne heavy oil and 19 tonne diesel due to cyclonic winds and rough seas, in late October. After a long delay, MPT picked Dutch firm Marine Masters B V to salvage the vessel and pump out the naphtha.

The chemical was being shifted out of India by another chemical tanker MT Global Peak to the Gulf at no cost to Goa or MPT.

The high court of judicature at Bombay, admiralty and vice-admiralty jurisdiction and its commercial division had ordered the auction of Nu-Shi Nalini by January 3, to pay Samson Maritime Ltd for expenses incurred to tow the vessel from Kerala to Goa, for the operation to remove naphtha and the salvage operations.

Title: Manager of technical college arrested in scholarship scam
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR: Haridwar police on Friday arrested the absconding manager of a technical college in connection with the multi-crore SC/ST scholarship scam .

Police said that the accused, identified as Amit Kumar, managed to get scholarship of 60 students worth Rs 15.41 lakh by using fake documents from the social welfare department.

He was booked last year under section 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), and 471 (using a forged document or electronic record as genuine) of the Indian Penal Code.

SHO of Jawalapur police station Yogesh Dev said, “We were trying to nab Kumar and our teams had even visited his residence in Meerut but he had managed to escape. Finally, he have arrested him from Vivek Vihar on Friday and will produce him before court.”

Title: Ahmedabad: No taxes for smart societies, conditions apply
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The 650-odd families of Orchid Whitefield residential society in Makarba pay roughly Rs 14.11 lakh in property taxes each year to the municipal corporation. There is an opportunity for them, and members of other societies in the city, to save taxes under the Smart Society Incentive Scheme announced by the municipal commissioner. The corporation has set aside Rs 50 crore for the purpose.“The conditions for tax waivers are that the societies must adhere to segregating wastes, properly manage and recycle garbage, conserve water and take other such measures like saving power and focus on greenery,” said an AMC official.Based on these factors, the AMC will give a star rating to each society. A three-star rating will mean 25% tax waiver, 4-star rating will signify 50% waiver and a 5-star rated society will get a 100% waiver.“We have for the first time tried to incentivize good civic practices through this scheme and hope a number of societies will come forward,” said municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra. Senior AMC officials added that if societies which are devoid of open space for greening or waste segregation, the civic body will extend help in these situations and even offer it’s own open spaces so that members could carry out plantation drives.

Title: Uttarakhand clinches third position in kayaking, canoeing tournament
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Uttarakhand had sent a delegation of 12 people, 10 of them sportspersons, to the event. However, they managed ... Read More

ROORKEE: The Uttarakhand team bagged one gold, four silvers and four bronzes in the 30th National Kayaking & Canoeing Senior Championships, which was concluded on Thursday in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. The state team secured an overall third position in the tournament.

The tournament had two categories, senior men's and women's. Uttarakhand had sent a delegation of 12 people, 10 of them sportspersons, to the event. However, they managed to win medals only in the canoeing events.

Due to lack of infrastructure for their sport, the participants practiced in the Old Gangnahar canal. Seven junior players from Boys Sports Company of BEG&C, Roorkee, one man and two girls from the local Shivalik Water Sports Club participated in the Bhopal event.

Uttarakhand team coach Amarjit Singh, who is also a subedar at BEG &C said, “We won one gold, four silvers and four bronzes in the canoeing events. Total 28 teams from different states and establishments participated in the championship. We secured the third position overall. The Madhya Pradesh team and the Services team won the first and second positions respectively.”

Title: Carnival to be held from Feb 22 to 25
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Panaji: The Carnival float parade will be held in the state from February 22 to 25.

The commissioner of the Corporation of the City of Panaji suggested changing the Carnival float parade route from the existing Miramar to Dona Paula to Paryatan Bhavan, Patto to Azad Maidan, Panaji, via old Patto bridge- behind old secretariat - Panaji Church – from commercial point.

Also, the committee members of Margao Carnival float parade decided to restore the old route from Margao Holy Spirit Church to Margao Municipal Building to old bus stand instead of Fatorda. The routes at Mapusa and Vasco will remain unchanged.

The float parade will be held at Panaji on February 22. At Margao and Quepem it will be held on February 23. Similarly, at Vasco and Curchorem the parade will be held on February 24 and at Mapusa and Morjim on February 25.

There has also been revision in prize structures this year with only five prizes to be awarded in the traditional category. Prizes in the club/institution, family, clown/joker for carnival and funk junk category has been dropped.

Title: Kolkata shines as two youths top the chart in CA exams
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Two from the city—both former students at St Xavier’s College (Autonomous)—topped the chartered accountants ( CA ) final examinations, held in November last year.The city has a track record of candidates faring well in CA final exams, but topping the exams was definitely an achievement, said senior chartered accountant Kamal Jain, lauding the feat by Abhay Bajoria and Dhruv Kothari .Bajoria will now apply in the placement cell at the Institute of Chartered Accountancy of India, looking for a job. “The planning began a year ago, when I was doing articleship, a compulsory three-year programme. We usually get a five-month study leave to prepare for the final exams and this was the period, I chalked out my study plan carefully. I made sure that I completed by tuition before the period so that I could fully concentrate on studying. The curriculum is vast and extremely complicated, which needs several revision,” Bajoria told TOI.His mother was the inspiration and motivation behind his success. “Whatever I have achieved is because of her,” said Bajoria, whose father died in 2016.Elaborating on his preparations, he said he had made a time-table and would put a tick on the date, he would finish a section he had targeted to complete. On days he would not be able to study the entire section, he would put a cross against the date. “I would devote around 12 hours a day to studying. Even if I failed, I knew that I have had put in considerable effort. Every day was a new beginning,” said Bajoria, a former student of Hariyana Vidya Mandir. He finished his BCom from St Xavier’s College (Autonomous) Kolkata in 2018. “I was a school-topper and also secured the highest rank in college. I was confident of cracking the CA exams and securing high marks. But the rank is a surprise. I want to work in the finance sector, preferably in investment banking or private equity. I aim to do a course of Executive MBA. Entrepreneurship is also on the radar,” he added.A self-confessed cricket fanatic, the Baguiati resident said even 15 days before the exam, he would binge-watch web series and films while taking a break from studies.Kothari, the other topper, said he was also looking for jobs, preferred areas being management, consultancy, merger, acquisitions and investment. “After acquiring some job experience, I might study for MBA,” he said. A student of Birla High School, Dhruv also graduated from St Xavier’s College (Autonomous) and lives in Minto Park. “I completed my tuition before the five-month study leave began so that I could focus on the curriculum properly. I knew my score would be good,” Kothari added. His advice for candidates is simple: finish the entire syllabus and be confident; revision before the examination is important. Son of a businessman and a homemaker, Dhruv plays professional cricket. “But I took a break in 2018 to concentrate on the exams. Now, I shall resume my hobbies,” he said.

Title: Ex-Merces sarpanch ends life over property row
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Police at the scene of the incident in Merces

Title: Study Juvenile Justice Act, Asaduddin Owaisi tells CDS Bipin Rawat
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Friday took pot-shots at Chief of Defence Staff (CDS) Bipin Rawat for ‘de-radicalisation’ comment and asked him to study Juvenile Act properly. During a conclave in Delhi on Thursday, the CDS said young children who being radicalised need to be identified and placed in de-radicalisation camps

Addressing a gathering in Korutla, Owaisi said, “The CDS says we will de-radicalise the children who are being radicalised, but I want to tell the CDS General saab, please read the Juvenile Act. IPC is not applicable on children, but he says that children will be taken to a separate place to be de-radicalised.”

Referring to a recent video of Meerut SP telling a group of anti-CAA protesters to leave the country and go to Pakistan, Owaisi said, “General saab you speak about de-radicalisation, but Meerut SP, along with police force, goes to areas which have Muslim population and asks people to go to Pakistan. He also gives them jail threats. Who will de-radicalise such SPs?”

Asad also mentioned about Hafiz Junaid and Tabrez Ansari, both were victims in lynching cases. Owaisi asked, “Who will de-radicalise people/groups who are attacking Muslims and Dalits? Who will de-radicalise people who killed Akhlaq and Pehlu Khan.”

Without naming Bhopal MP Pragya Thakur, Owaisi said BJP has given an MP ticket to a terror accused.

On BJP general secretary Ram Madhav’s statement that Hitler and Mussolini were products of democracy, but democracies mature over time, Owaisi tweeted, “Savarkar & Gowalkar were big bhakts of Nazism/fascism in Europe. Today, this ‘bhakti’ is proved by the fact that a terror accused is a ruling party MP. To protest peacefully is a democratic right. To call for badla & goli against protestors is peak Nazism.”

Title: Three child labourers rescued
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Mangaluru: Officials of the labour department and department of public instruction rescued three child labourers who were working in a fish processing unit at Hoige Baazar on Friday.

Victims from Bihar

Officials said that the rrescued children were working as fish cutters and hailed from Bihar.

They have been rescued, and a case has been booked against the unit owner, said sources.

Shop gutted; suspicion that it was set ablaze

An automobile spare parts shop got gutted in Derlakatte on Friday. It is suspected that miscreants may have set fire to the shop.

According to police, the incident came to light on Friday morning, when shopowner Suresh Rai opened the shop.

It is suspected that miscreants set fire to the shop on Thursday night and fled from the spot.

A few days back, a truck was set on fire, which was carrying chairs in the same locality.

Title: E-Way: ‘Delayed’ report on mitigation steps miffs wildlife experts
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Nagpur: Tempers flared during a meet on Friday morning between forest department, Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation ( MSRDC ) and the High Powered Committee (HPC) set up to look into mitigation measures being taken to protect wildlife on the 800km-odd stretch of the under-construction Mumbai-Nagpur Samruddhi Mahamarg .

The flare-up was triggered after HPC members alleged that they received a report on mitigation measures just ‘a few days ago’ even though government had access to it since at least November. This delay, HPC members claimed, prevented them from taking an informed decision and giving an opinion on it.

The report was prepared by Wildlife Institute of India (WII). Kishore Rithe, member of HPC, said “The expert members were given a soft copy of the report just a few days back and it was impossible for us to put forth our views. It is an exhaustive report which took over a year to be completed, so obviously it can’t be read in just in a few days.”

HPC members have now proposed that they will give their opinion on the matter after not only going through the report but also conducting site visits. Rithe said, “It is important for us to get a ground-level feel after reading the report and consulting other stakeholders.”

Not commenting specifically on some expert members being miffed, state PCCF (wildlife) Nitin Kakodkar said that HPC expert members were not mandated to give their opinion on the same day itself. “Expert members can go through the report and put their say in the next meeting,” said Kakodkar.

It has been decided that HPC members will first hold consultations with other stakeholders on January 22, followed by site visit in the first week of February. Rithe said, “On February 15, we will meet again to finalize our view based on the report, consultations and site visit.”

MSRDC, the government agency executing the project, says they are open to suggestions from all experts. Radheshyam Mopalwar, chairman of MSRDC, said, “We have already gone beyond the call for conserving eco-sensitive zones and will implement suggestions made in the report. Apart from that we will ensure that any improvement suggested by HPC members is also implemented. Our aim is to construct the most greenest and compliant highway in the country.”

The way ahead

* Expert members to meet with other stakeholders on Jan 22

* Site visits on February 4 and 5

* Second meet on February 15

Title: Uttarakhand: Man held for making obscene video of tenant girls
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR: A 35-year-old man was arrested by Haridwar police on Friday evening on charges of voyeurism. The man had secretly shot obscene videos of two girls, who were living as tenants in his house, while they were bathing. The arrest was made after the girls filed a complaint against accused Rajneesh Kumar, a Shanti Vihar resident.

According to police, one of the girls felt suspicious while bathing on Friday morning. She suddenly opened the door and caught the accused landlord making her video on his mobile phone. She started screaming and managed to snatch the mobile phone. Reportedly, the accused and his wife tried to “reach a settlement” but the girls approached the police.

SHO Jawalapur police station Yogesh Dev told TOI, “The accused has been arrested a case has been registered against him. His mobile phone has been also seized and further investigation is underway. The girls have alleged that he had been making their video secretly for a long time.”

Title: Smart City mission: DPRs for 11 projects worth Rs 935 crore soon
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Development: File photo of Smart City work in Mangaluru

Mangaluru: Mangaluru Smart City Limited (MSCL) managing director Mohammed Nazeer called upon citizens to cooperate with the authorities for the implementation of various projects to be taken up under the Smart City mission .

At an interaction programme with various organisations and institutions, Nazeer said that while several works have already been taken up, the MSCL has already prepared action plans for many future projects. “While there are 45 projects before the MSCL, 13 are being implemented under the pan city scheme. Meanwhile, 32 works are aimed at development of regions. We have identified eight wards measuring 1,628 acres to implement projects worth Rs 2,000.7 crore. City development, greenery and regional development will be given emphasis while implementing Smart City projects. The pan city development also involves incorporation of technology to develop the city’s infrastructure,” he said.

LED lamps have been installed at various places in the city at a cost of Rs 1.9 crore. A clock tower has been constructed at a cost of Rs 75 lakh at Hampankatta. Development of the Clock Tower-A B Shetty Circle road is being taken up at an estimated cost of Rs 6.2 crore. A total 18 works which are being taken up at an estimated cost of Rs 477.7 crore are under progress, he said.

Tenders have been invited for the construction of a swimming pool of international standards for Rs 24.9 crore, development of Kadri Park at Rs 12 crore, Command and Control Centre (Rs 5 crore), skill development centre (Rs 4.8 crore) and 10 other projects worth Rs 77.8 crore. Meanwhile, detailed project reports (DPR) are being prepared for 11 projects to be taken up at an estimated cost of Rs 935 crore, he added.

Title: FRI holds 2-day training for forest officials
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020
