NEW DELHI: Advance planning and quick reaction by the Leh district administration saved over 100 lives after two groups of trekkers and their crew were marooned in sub-zero temperatures when sudden gush of snowmelt submerged parts of the ‘Chadar’ trek route on the frozen Zanskar river in the newly-created Union Territory of Ladakh .

At around 6.30 pm last Saturday, communication lines at the district headquarters crackled to life. The message was terse: About 71 trekkers and their support personnel were trapped between Camps 2 and 3 at Tibb and Neyraks villages, respectively, some 70 km from Leh, as the frozen river patch became inundated. Whereabouts of 40-odd trekkers were uncertain.

“This year we had posted three SDRF (State Disaster Relief Force) personnel and team guides, who are expert mountaineers or trekkers, at each of the three camps for emergency response. This came in handy and we immediately activated these personnel to start locating the trekkers and alerted the IAF ( Indian Air Force ) for imminent evacuation in the morning,” Leh deputy commissioner Sachin Kumar Vaishya told TOI on Friday.

These rescue teams carried out the search operation through the next day and guided the trekkers to safer ground as water level kept rising, making the frozen patches risky to cross. Vaishya also praised the support staff for their knowledge of the topography and help. Bad weather, however, stalled evacuation by air on Sunday and began only after the weather cleared.

The incident forced the administration to suspend the trek for two days to avoid putting “more groups at risk” if the snow kept melting at such faster pace. Concerned locals at Leh told TOI over phone the incident underpins the negative impact of unchecked tourism on Ladakh’s fragile ecology and should be taken as a warning sign.

The annual trek is globally known for the out-of-this-world view it affords the trekkers. It is also notorious for the perilous journey on the frozen river bed, with temperature dipping 30 degrees below freezing.

Title: After Kerala, Punjab House passes anti-CAA resolution
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

CHANDIGARH: Punjab on Friday became the second state after Kerala to pass an assembly resolution seeking repeal of the contentious Citizenship (Amendment) Act, with chief minister Amarinder Singh calling the new law “inherently discriminatory” and redolent of the “ethnic and religious cleansing in Hitler’s Germany”.

The resolution, supported by AAP and opposed by Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD), also demands changes in the documentation required for inclusion of names in the National Population Register.

Amarinder said like Kerala, the Congress government in Punjab would soon move the Supreme Court against the amended citizenship law.

In the assembly, the CM set the tone for the debate on the resolution by asking those opposing it to read Adolf Hitler ’s ‘Mein Kampf ’ to “understand the dangers of CAA”. He offered to get the book translated and distributed among them.

“What happened in Germany under Hitler in 1930 is happening in India now. Germans did not speak then, and they regretted it. But we have to speak now so we don’t regret later,” he said. “Clearly, no lessons have been learnt from history. What is happening in India is not good for the country, which is why people are protesting spontaneously — without any instigation.”

SAD argued instead of repealing the Act, it should be amended to include Muslims among the eligible applicants for citizenship. “I want to ask if you are against Sikhs and Hindus. If not, you should have only asked for Muslims to be added to the eligibility list. Let’s not play politics. Hardly 800-900 people in Punjab will be affected. SAD opposes the resolution,” legislature party leader S S Dhillon said.

The resolution was moved by parliamentary affairs minister Brahm Mohindra and put to vote by Speaker Rana KP Singh at 3.18pm.

Finance minister Manpreet Singh Badal was the first to back the resolution, saying opposing CAA was in line with Punjab’s “secular history”. “CAA is divisive in nature. Why should Tamils from Lanka, Rohingiyas of Myanmar and Ahmediyas from Pakistan be left out?” he said. Leader of the Opposition H S Cheema declared AAP’s support to the resolution.

Title: Ahmedabad: Calorx Teachers’ University under scanner for doctoring PhD process
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

After a slew of complaints, the department has sent a show-cause notice to the university

Title: Asia Bibi case: Pak sentences 86 to 55-yr jail for protests
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

ISLAMABAD: A court in Pakistan has sentenced the brother and nephew of a radical party chief along with 84 others to 55-year prison terms each for taking part in protests in 2018 over the acquittal of Asia Bibi, a Christian woman in a controversial blasphemy case, according to a media report.

The anti-terrorism court (ATC) was hearing a case against the Tehreek-i-Labbaik Pakistan (TLP) workers who held violent protests and clashed with police over the arrest of party chief Khadim Hussain Rizvi in 2018, Dawn news reported.

Those convicted include TLP chief Khadim Hussain Rizvi’s brother Ameer Hussain Rizvi and nephew Mohammad Ali, the report said. The court on Thursday also ordered the convicts to collectively submit Rs 12,925,000 and directed authorities to seize their moveable and immoveable assets.

In November 2018, over 2,000 people, including the chief of a radical party, were booked under terrorism and other charges of rioting, attempting murder and hurling threats in different parts of Punjab province during the three-day protests following Bibi’s acquittal.

Title: Students’ bodies flay NU for reval refund mess
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Nagpur: A day after Nagpur University (NU) vice-chancellor SP Kane admitted to lapse on its administration’s part over spreading awareness on refund scheme for revaluation, various students’ organizations demanded that NU should make up for its blunder by informing those students who cleared papers.

An RTI information secured by activist Abhay Kolarkar disclosed that over 2.14 lakh students applied for revaluation in six examinations conducted from 2016 to 2019.

“Refund of revaluation money to the students was our long-pending demand, but NU authorities were reluctant to accept it for all these years. Why should a student suffer for NU evaluator’s fault? The authorities must refund the money of students who cleared the exams after revaluation,” NSUI’s Ajit Singh said.

He said the NU miserably failed to spread awareness about various schemes for the students. “You go to any campus. They didn’t paste any notice about such schemes. How do you expect the students to know about them? And then you say that no student approached them,” he added.

Some students told TOI that when they approached for refund till last year, the exam section officials used to tell them that such a scheme was never implemented and only a proposal was submitted.

“Last year only, we had submitted a representation in this regard to the VC. When nothing progressed, we staged a peaceful protest. But, we were manhandled by the guards and false complaints were lodged against us. I was falsely implicated for speaking the truth,” ABVP activist Vaibhav Bawankar said.

ABVP’s city unit head Amit Patle accused the VC of misleading students by stating that none of them approached for refund. “I can give proofs that I went to former Board of Examination and Evaluation (BOEE) director Neeraj Khaty with many students for refunding the revaluation amount. They only offer excuses that NU will be starting online system which never became a reality. Once they told us that refund would be granted from the exam section, but that too didn’t materialize,” he said.

BOEE director Prafulla Sable told TOI that he would be sitting with the VC to finalize modalities for refunding the amount. “We will be doing it after the convocation. So far, no such rules were framed,” the said.

Patle said none of the NU officers from the exam section knew about existence of such a scheme. “Even students from other districts like Gondia, Wardha and Bhandara were confused on this aspect,” he said.

Title: BMC ex-chief engineer has Dubai property: Enforcement Directorate
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Enforcement Directorate

MUMBAI: Enforcement Directorate (ED) searched premises of former chief engineer of BMC's development plan (DP) department, Devendra Natvarlal Desai , after registering a case under Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) on Friday. Desai retired from BMC about a decade back.

ED officials said they found that Desai had invested in a property in Dubai, from which he was earning an annual rent of Rs 13 lakh. He had transferred Rs 40 lakh to his US-based married daughter.

ED searched his premises after obtaining information through sources that the engineer had amassed money during his tenure in BMC. He allegedly diverted it abroad, violating rules. During the search, ED officials said they collected documents showing the foreign assets and the money transfer.

The engineer, ED said, purchased the property in Bonaire Marsa building, Park Island, Dubai, in 2012, by paying Rs 70 lakh. He purchased the property in his name, along with wife and son. ED questioned him about the purchase details of property, source of money and mode of payment. The engineer was unable to provide details and officials suspect that the property had been purchased through illegal money, officials said.

ED found several documents during the search, which shows that the property is on rent and the engineer's family is earning UAE dirham 65,000 (approximately Rs 13 lakh) yearly from it. They also found documents showing money transfer to his daughter in US.

The chief engineer (DP) is considered crucial as construction files of Mumbai's builders go to him for clearance. Most architects sometimes meet the chief engineer with designs and project files.

Title: 10 asst commrs get show cause notice
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) standing committee headed by Pradip Pohane on Tuesday issued show cause notices to assistant commissioners of all ten zones for low recovery of property tax. This was the outcome of municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar’s decision to levy cut of 25% in the budget presented by Pohane.

Pohane told TOI the cut in the budget is due to low recovery of property tax. “I have also directed the administration not to levy cut on funds and works sanctioned by the state government. NMC has no right to stop works sanctioned by the government. The civic chief did not levy cut on works proposed under fixed priority, backward class, and persons with disabilities. If we consider all such excluded heads, cut will become minimal,” he said.

Pohane had presented a budget of Rs3,197.60 crore in which he approved works of Rs3,197.34 crore. Bangar had imposed cut on works costing Rs772 crore.

Pohane directed the property tax department and assistant commissioners of all 10 zones to ensure recovery of property tax at par with target set in budget. In nine months of current fiscal, property tax revenue is around Rs170 crore where as target set in budget was Rs443.70 crore.

The standing committee gave powers to civic chief to take further decision on completion of works remaining under Cement Concrete Road Project phase-I. NMC’s projects department sought approval to offer work to second or third lowest bidders Mahalsa Constructions and JP Enterprises, respectively, or go for re-tender in case the two companies refused to work at the rate quoted by first lowest bidder Abhi Engineering. Following inordinate delay in issuing work order, Abhi Engineering has refused to execute the work.

The delay will result in severe inconvenience to citizens as nine roads pending for concretization for last nine years are now full of potholes and bad surface layer.

Other Decisions

* No hike in property tax for next fiscal 2020-21 after steep rise two years ago

* NMC to fund Rs25 lakh for International Film Festival

* Extension to 13 fire personnel for four more months on contractual basis

* Work orders of Rs44.03 lakh for development of Samvedna Park at Shivaji Nagar garden

* Appointment of Shree Siddhi Vinayak Pratishthan for operation and maintenance of fitness centre developed at Panchdeep Layout, Bhamti

Title: Misleading post against Mohan Bhagwat: RSS lodges plaint
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh ( RSS ) has lodged a complaint with Kotwali police against unidentified persons for circulating a misleading PDF against the organization and its chief Mohan Bhagwat on social media.

The post, titled Naya Samvidhan (new constitution), has Bhagwat’s picture and word on an imaginary constitution of the country dominated by the upper caste.

Some of the content shared by the RSS at a press conference includes lines stating that the new constitution is based on Hindu religion and even citizenship and jobs will be based on caste. The upper caste will be first class citizens with the lowest status given to the lower caste, it says.

Shridhar Gadge, RSS’ Mahanagar Sah Sanchalak (deputy chief of the city unit), said the post intends to malign the image of the organization. “It appears that the content has been posted to deliberately target the masses and mislead them. We have requested the police to trace the origin of the post and even block it,” he said. The RSS has termed the attempt as a means to gain unfair political mileage.

The post comes at a time when statements against the RSS have been made during the anti-NRC and CAA rallies in the city. During protest meetings, speakers alleged that the RSS and the BJP were intending to make the country a Hindu nation dominated by the upper caste.

Title: Lucknow: Relative held for raping minor girl
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Title: VNIT to train engrs on making roads safer
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Nagpur: The Union ministry of road transport and highways has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with six premier engineering institutions including Nagpur’s Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT) to provide training to engineers in new road safety, engineering, development and maintenance technology.

Funded by World Bank and Asian Development Bank, the Central government will provide Rs14,000 crore to provide training to 72,000 engineers across the country for three years.

“As per the MoU, VNIT will assist in evaluation and introduction of new technology for road safety and operational efficiencies. We will train 6,000 engineers from various government organisations like public works department, municipal corporations from central Indian states including Odisha, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Telangana and part of Gujarat,” confirmed VNIT’s civil engineering HoD V Landge.

Union minister for road transport and highways Nitin Gadkari, defence minister Rajnath Singh and minister of state for road transport and highways VK Singh were present when VNIT signed the MoU with MoRTH on January 13 in New Delhi, he said.

It has been observed that apart from human negligence, faulty road and infrastructure designs too contribute in road accidents. So the training programme has been designed to improve road designing and construction.

“The 15-day course has been designed by the World Bank and the contents include road safety awareness, road geometrics including shoulders, surface of the roads and then giving training on how to carry out road safety audit (RSA),” Landge said.

RSA is an important aspect after construction of any road. It actually certifies whether the road is good for traffic or not. The audit also includes night time safety. The World Bank also focuses on safety of elderly motorists while designing a road, said Landge. “According to World Bank, age behind the wheels is fast increasing. Seniors now have to carry out their chores on their own. Due to their advanced stage, they are involved in accidents. So specific modules have been given,” Landge said.

VNIT has been given target to train 6,000 engineers in three years. “We have to take three batches of 15 days each,” he said. The VNIT professor said the institute was also planning to open road safety training centre in the city.

Course Modules

* Road safety, engineering, development and maintenance

* How to carry out road safety audit

* Night traffic study

* Safety of elderly motorists

Title: Sea of cool styles too at Happy Streets
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Nagpur: Besides the enthusiasm, the style quotient is also high during chilly winter mornings at Happy Streets , a Times of India and Maharashtra Times initiative. From 6-9am on Sundays, the yoga section, maybe, turns a few heads less than the latest winter wear on the stretch from Laxmi Bhuvan Square to Law College Square.

With all the novel activities around, dressing up for winters does not mean the cozy and comfortable outfits can sacrifice practicality. Nagpurians have shown that they know well how winter fashion can blend style and function.

Shreya Kewalramani, a student, said, “I am a regular visitor at Happy Streets and I love to put on some over-sized sweaters and a printed floral scarf with boots to complete my look.” On how she manages to pull it off early in the morning, she said, “I love dressing up and I leave no occasion to present the best of me.”

Some citizens rock trendy sports wear with neon colour boots and sports shoes, while some do not shy away from wearing eye-catching short dresses and night wear turned into causal outfits. “I don't mind wearing nice shorts and knee-length dresses in the morning, but sometimes I step out wearing bright colour turtleneck sweaters to Happy Streets,” said Ashrayee Wasnik, a student.

“Happy Streets gives an opportunity and motivation to wake up in the morning, dress up and start the day on a happy and positive note,” added Wasnik

The sustained cold weather has given people an excuse to stock up on winter wardrobe staples, which year after year, and never go out of style. “I see a lot of people wearing stylish clothes at Happy Streets, which means our city is becoming very fashion conscious,” said Mehak Lakhwani, a student.

“I love to wear knitted sweaters and throwing on some funky accessories on my head, like pins and bands. I also don’t leave house without putting on my favourite eye lens, especially if I am visiting Happy Streets,” she added.

Right from fashionable pullovers to leather jackets to short summer dresses and long sleeve turtle necks, citizens are rocking every style. A few people stand out from the crowd with their layered outfits and matching accessories. “I love experimenting with my style, and it’s so much fun to come up with a new outfit idea each Sunday for Happy Streets,” said Aparajita Mahajan, a student.

Girls are also very particular with make-up, and a peppy lip shade and kohl in the eyes are a must even early in the morning, “Makeup completes any look, and adds more confidence,” added Mahajan.

Even senior citizens can be seen putting on blanket scarfs, with chunky knit cardigan sweaters or bundled up under a favourite puffer, keeping them warm from head to toe. Young boys can be seen smartly dressed in high-boots, heavy jackets and sunglasses.

Bhargavi Wanjari’s style statement was bow-shaped hairband and crop top. “I always like to dress up in an unique manner. I see very few people here who had a hairstyle like me, it’s very unique and makes me stand out in the crowd on the streets,” said Wanjari.

Title: Kolkata News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Kolkata: Like any measure of sporting greatness, only some things are quantifiable, the others just a collective ‘idea’ in the minds of fans and connoisseurs. How many international goals did Maradona score? How old was he when the infamous ‘Hand of God’ happened? These are questions that are easily answerable. But what’s not so easy to qualify, let alone quantify, is that undefinable quality of his shimmering, almost other-worldly, run with the ball towards the opponents’ goal. Harder to define is that collective magic he wove on everyone the moment he stepped out on the field.

Similarly, Mohun Bagan ’s existence as a football club is easily quantifiable. It was founded in 1889, thus making it 130-going-on-131 years old. Also, for a die-hard fan, it wouldn’t be difficult to find out how many club victories it has had over the years, how many times it beat East Bengal on the Maidan or even which year its ‘barefoot team’ created history by winning the IFA Shield after beating the East Yorkshire regiment 2-1. What is difficult to define about this Maidan institution is the electric atmosphere on the ground when its faces its arch-rivals. Or, for that matter, why this Mohun Bagan-East Bengal rivalry is such a huge thing, almost a measure of one’s Bengali-ness.

It is, thus, only natural that any decision regarding the club or the football team would evoke a lot of interest and reaction.

It’s been that way since Thursday’s announcement that RPSG Group, which owns and runs Indian Super League ( ISL ) side ATK FC and Mohun Bagan Football Club (India) Private Limited — that controls the Mohun Bagan football team — will come together to form a new team. The new entity, which will come into existence from June 1 this year, is set to be called ATK Mohun Bagan, with RPSG Group holding 80% shares and Mohun Bagan Football Club (India) Private Limited having the remaining 20%.

The merged team will play in the ISL from next season but Mohun Bagan have the I-League to negotiate this season and will hope to end their I-League sojourn as champions.

Bagan, the table-toppers, will play their first match after this development on Sunday, when they face arch-rivals East Bengal at the Salt Lake Stadium, even as the green-and-maroon faithful weigh in on the new move.

“I have a tattoo of the Mohun Bagan logo on my hand... that will never change,” says ardent supporter Tamal Bose. “Also, this association is not with the club. I think the logo and jersey colour will not be altered. When I was young, both Mohun Bagan and East Bengal had their respective sponsors’ names before the team’s name. Even when the merged team comes into existence, the essence of the Kolkata derby will always remain as the fight between the green-and-maroons and the red-and-golds.”

Sounav Dhawa holds a similar view. “This is a good initiative. I have no issues with ATK being prefixed to Mohun Bagan because whoever invests will surely promote their brand. I will be very happy to see better players turn out for the team,” he said, adding, “The derby will always remain a derby. The Bagan entity is most important.”

Saikat Bose, who stays in Mumbai and is part of the Mumbai-Pune Mariners fans’ group, has a bit of an itch about the ATK Mohun Bagan nomenclature.

“ATK prefixed to Mohun Bagan is something I don’t like much,” he says. “We have to see how the whole thing actually pans out now. It’s better if the logo and jersey colour remains the same. The Kolkata derby will remain the same from the next season as well. The statistics will not show it as the first match-up between the two teams. It will carry the same heritage and passion. For Sunday’s match, we have arranged for a screening in Mumbai. So far, everyone is attending.”

There, however, are a few who have been extremely perturbed by the name of the new team. “Till June 1, the team is Mohun Bagan. So, I have no problem attending any of the matches and I will go to watch Sunday’s derby. I feel, owing to the history, the Kolkata derby will not lose its value from the next season as well. But I might not turn up at the ground. I have no issue with the shareholding pattern but can’t accept ATK Mohun Bagan as the name. Why not something like Kolkata Mohun Bagan? If the name stays, I’ll probably not attend the team’s matches from next season,” says 36-year-old Debashis Bhattacharyya, who has been a Maidan regular since 1997.

Dipayan Bhattacharya, on the other hand, wants to look at the developments with pragmatism. “An investor was needed for us in order to make a big-budget team. Even when we had a sponsor’s name before the team’s name, we went to watch the matches and we also won many trophies. Also, as far as the Kolkata derby is concerned, the passion will never die down,” the 40-year old feels.

Title: Noida: New police commissionerate headquarters may be shifted to traffic park
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Representative image

NOIDA: The headquarters of the new police commissionerate will most likely be shifted to the traffic park in Sector 108 and inaugurated by chief minister Yogi Adityanath .

Sources said the police department had requested the Authority for space and an in-principle approval has been given by the CEO. “The formal approval is likely to be given early next week while the office will be shifted by the end of this month,” said an official of Noida Authority .

The traffic park in Sector 108 was developed by the Noida Authority and inaugurated by the CM last year. It is already slated to house the regional transport office and the traffic police office.

Meanwhile, new police stations are likely to come up in Gautam Budh Nagar district in the next few days. The police headquarters moved a proposal to state government to set up new police stations in Noida. Owing to the growing population of the city, the local police wanted to create four new police stations. The four new police stations proposed are Okhla Barrage, Sector 106, Sector 115 and Sector 63. A total of 22 police stations, including the women’s police station, are functioning in the district currently. About 1,200 additional police personnel will join the force in Noida soon.

Title: Aadhaar, voter ID are no proof of citizenship: Dilip Ghosh
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

File photo of Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh

HOWRAH: Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh, taking a cue from Union home minister Amit Shah, has said that Aadhaar card and voter ID are no proof of citizenship .

“Having an Aadhaar card and voter card doesn’t entitle one to be a citizen,” Ghosh told a party gathering in Howrah on Friday, days after chief minister Mamata Banerjee urged people to get their names correctly enrolled in the voters’ list. “Get your names correctly enrolled in the voters’ list and leave the rest to us,” the CM had said.

Ghosh stirred a controversy while taking on Banerjee, who claimed the other day that migrants may asked to produce birth certificates of their parents. “Let those who are not sure about their parents bother about it. They are trying to confuse people. We need not worry,” he said.

The comment drew an immediate response from TMC. “I have never seen a politician like Dilip Ghosh in my political career who can stoop to such a low,” TMC’s Baranagar MLA Tapas Ray said. BJP has no right to decide who is a citizen and who isn’t, Ray added.

The Bengal BJP president urged people not to listen to what the CM is saying. “Those coming from Bangladesh have to apply for citizenship. The PM will give you three to four months to apply for citizenship under CAA . The application should include the refugee’s name, his father’s name, place (in Bangladesh) from where he came and the date of entry to India. There are some who came in 1975, some in 1980 and some after that. All those who came to India from Bangladesh before December 31, 2014 are eligible to apply. The self-certified application is enough. Please mention the date and place in your application correctly,” Ghosh said.

R&AW, during its submission to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2016 has stated it will verify the “religious persecution” clause mentioned in the application.

Bengal BJP leaders, while backing Ghosh’s view that Aadhaar card and voter card can’t be taken as citizenship proof, didn’t rule out such an inquiry. “Non-Muslims comi-ng from the three countries — Bangladesh, Pakistan and Afghanistan — have to make a self-certified application. Now, if somebody makes a complaint against him, the onus lies on the applicant under the Foreigner’s Act, and not on the complainant, to prove that what he mentioned in his application is true. He may be asked to produce documents in support of his claim even if he has an Aadhaar card and voter card,” a Bengal BJP leader said.

Ghosh urged people not to worry about the birth certificates of parents. “These are all bunkum. Nobody is going to ask for these. Your applicat-ion is enough. We need not wo-rry,” Ghosh said, after leading a rally from Howrah’s Dumurjala to Howrah Maidan.

Title: Where the streets have one name
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Kolkata: In Agantuk, Satyajit Ray’s last movie, central character Manomohan says something that is perhaps a hint that he, despite spending more than three decades outside the country, is at heart a Bengali still. When Manomohan’s family, sceptical about his identity — and learning that he has lived in Brazil — ask him about football and Pelé, he answers that for him, football means Mohun Bagan and East Bengal .

To slightly twist a popular saying, you can take the Bengali football fan out of Bengal, but you cannot take the Mohun Bagan-East Bengal rivalry out of a true-blue Bengali football fan. And this Maidan romanticism is what Ray expresses so succinctly through Manomohan. Which is why this marriage — between ATK and Mohun Bagan — has vertically cleaved the latter club’s vast body of fans, whose number could easily rival, if not sometimes eclipse, the entire population of some European countries.

In the heartland of Bagan fandom — Mohun Bagan Lane, Mohun Bagan Row, Kirti Mitra Lane in Fariapukur, opinion is fairly divided, but the majority feels that the marriage was perhaps inevitable in the current scenario. Ranjoy Das — whose father, Mani Das, was the football secretary of Mohun Bagan for 22 years till 2005 — believes the union would be really good for Bagan. Das runs his family shop just 10 metres from the house of Bhupen Bose (Basu Batika), one of the founders of the green-and-maroons in 1889. “We have no other option but to play ISL ,” he says. “Only then will we get proper exposure and recognition. See, the I-League is already getting second-division treatment. I feel that soon, entry to the AFC Cup and other international competitions would be through the ISL. Supporters should not be worried about this (the club merger) now.”

Shree Narayan Tandon, who has a family business in Burrabazar, is another ardent supporter of the Mariners. Standing just 100 metres from Mohun Bagan Lane, he confesses he doesn’t know what the outcome of this would be. “I am a third-generation supporter of the club,” he proudly declares, narrating how he even turned away out-of-state customers from his shop because he had to go to the Maidan to watch a match. “This year, I drove down to Kalyani to see my team playing. My elder sister stays in London, but she has made it a point to renew her club membership every year,” he adds.

His only concern is what the new owners will do about members, or how they will use the Mohun Bagan brand.

There are some extreme views as well, like the one expressed by Sayak Das, a die-hard fan who stays near Mohun Bagan Row. “My personal view is that Mohun Bagan has sold out,” he says. “If one club takes over another, the existence of the latter is obviously at stake.” Another supporter, Dhruba Ghosal, who has been a fan for over 50 years, is also critical. “It was perhaps needed, but considering the heritage of our club, our name should come before ATK’s. It should be Mohun Bagan-ATK and not the other way round. Another thing is that our jersey and logo should prevail at any cost. Otherwise, we shall oppose this,” he says.

But for every naysayer, there are at least two fans who see the merger in a positive light. Utpal Bag, who runs a shop just 100 metres from Mohun Bagan Row, welcomes the move. He has been watching his favourite club play since 1976, becoming a member in 1982. “This was required,” he says. “Otherwise, how would the club run? How long will an individual finance the club? If you do not have big sponsors, you stand no chance in ISL, and the I-League will soon become second division.” Souvvik Ghosh, another ardent supporter, also has strong views about the deal. “My only concern is the derby. Otherwise, this is the best thing that could have happened to our team,” he says.

Title: Adhir plays down Bengal move to skip NPR meeting
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Midnapore: Lok Sabha Congress leader Adhir Chowdhury has played down the Bengal government’s decision to not send officials to Delhi for the NPR meet. “The meeting was called by the census commissioner. He didn’t invite any chief minister. State officials were called to discuss how to conduct the census and decide on parameters for conducting NPR,” he said.

Chowdhury pointed out that people had every right to oppose NPR parameters and tell officials they wouldn’t give the documents asked for. “But that is on the ground. That is more important than not sending state officials to Delhi. It doesn’t tie in with the CM calling on the PM at Raj Bhavan,” he said.

The Congress leader said the CM and PM are both trying to confuse people. “PM Modi had to invite Pakistan PM Imran Khan to the Sanghai Cooperation Organisation conclave. He cannot afford to antagonise China or Russia. He has, therefore, invited the Pakistan PM. But for us, he keeps making anti-Pakistan remarks,” he said.

Title: Bengal seeks civic body fund reports
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Kolkata: The West Bengal government has sought detailed fund utilisation reports from all poll-bound urban local bodies by March 31.

The municipal affairs department’s move is widely seen as a stock-taking exercise ahead of the polls.

The state election commission on Friday announced seat reservation for 91 urban local bodies which are due for polls in April-May. Seat reservations for Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation and Asansol-Durgapur Municipal Corporation are due in October and to Darjeeling Municipality in end-2020. tnn

Title: Picnic bus overturns in Asansol, 60 injured
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Raniganj: Around 60 people, including two children, were injured when a picnic bus overturned on NH-2 near Raniganj’s Punjabi More early on Friday.

Sixty-five people were going to a picnic at Rajarappa in Jharkhand from Tribeni. The bus hit the divider amid dense fog. The passengers were trapped inside. Alerted by locals, cops arrived and took the injured to hospital.

Title: Woman, kid’s convenience must decide divorce transfer case: Calcutta high court
Content:
This story is from January 18, 2020

Calcutta high court

KOLKATA: The inconvenience of the woman and the child should be “the prime consideration” when courts decide on pleas to transfer divorce petitions and child custody cases, the Calcutta High Court has said in a recent judgment.

The HC, in an eight-page order last week, transferred both the divorce proceedings and the child custody case from a Jalpaiguri court to one in Durgapur after a woman pleaded that she was unable to travel 600 kilometres from Durgapur to attend court proceedings in Jalpaiguri; she was financially dependent on her parents and her 13-year-old son studied in a local Durgapur school, she explained.

Justice Bibek Chaudhuri cited five Supreme Court orders that suggested “the inconvenience of the wife should be treated as the prime consideration” while deciding transfer petitions in matrimonial suits and referred to a 2018 Calcutta HC judgment while deciding on the transfer of the child custody case.

The high court, in the 2018 order, said the “legislative intent” behind child custody laws was not to force a child to attend a court hearing several hundred kilometres from where s/he stayed. Both the divorce and custody cases will now be heard by the Durgapur additional district judge.

The woman’s plea says she was married in February 2004 and had a child in June 2006. During marriage, she claimed, she was subjected to mental and physical abuse and was forced to leave her marital home and return to Durgapur after a physical attack on her in December 2017.

She learnt in 2018 that her husband had filed divorce proceedings.

She then filed a plea, seeking custody of her minor son. Neither the woman’s husband nor his advocate chose to respond to her petition in high court.
